speaker: Mr Speaker
theText: It being 11 o'clock, theTuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4755 Tuesday, 3 June 1997 (No.2) 1997 Second Reading Debate resumed from 29 May, on motion by Mr Anderson: That the bill be now read a second time. Amendment Bill (No.2) covers the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987. The reference to this is very minor. It reduces the size of the board, which I think is probably a good thing. It is certainly going to limit costs. I hope grower representation is maintained. Too often on these boards the interests of growers are subverted when the nominees come from agri-political bodies which have long ceased to have much relevance to the welfare of the grower or primary producer. With respect to AQIS, the bill gives the power for AQIS to license people meeting its standards to certify things for export. It is my view that self-regulation in this area is fraught with danger and is probably not in our long-term interest. Having said that, it is quite clear that something has to be done about the extraordinary cost imposed on exporters by AQIS. A lot of this has to do with AQIS' s regulations and rigmarole, which are designed to enhance its income rather than expedite the processing of exports. I could go into great detail about what I see as the shortcomings of AQIS in this regard. Like a lot of other countries, we should forget this nonsense of full cost recovery. AQIS should be seen as an adjunct to Australia's exports. It should be impressed upon it that its job is to help exports, not to hinder them. I believe that, in the long run, self-regulation will not be the way to go. Some people in this parliament will remember the meat scandals which were a direct result of corruption in the process of certifying meat. The proposed amendments to the Social Security Act covered by this bill will allow the recovery of drought relief overpayments that were paid to farmers through a variety of mechanisms. This is interesting. In my view, the drought relief paid to farmers was not very substantial, it was extremely hard to get, and overpayments in this area would be minimal. However, I am cynically amused that we are prepared to enshrine in legislation the methods of recovery from farmers, yet we will not do the same thing in respect -o some quasigovernment bodies such as housing authorities where there was an enormous demand from people to have their rents taken out of social security payments-particularly, I might add, from the Aboriginal community. We simply do not do it, and this is to the detriment of government bodies such as the Aboriginal housing corporations. In other areas, such as the payment of Abstudy, John Dawkins very foolishly took this payment away from schools and gave it to individuals. That means that schools no longer get the money. I took this matter up with the previous government. As I have said so often in this House, there is really no difference-we are dealing with Tweedledum and Tweedledumberand this government refuses to act on it as well.

speaker: Mr Campbell (Kalgoorlie) (4.30 P.m.)
theText: The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation4756 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 Under this agreement, imported food from New Zealand will be inspected-if it is inspected-at point of sale, not at point of entry. This is part of our agreement with New Zealand. One cannot help but become increasingly cynical about our trade agreement with New Zealand. We are told that, on balance, we export more to New Zealand. This is a nonsense when you think of the other advantages New Zealand gets. I suspect that the transfer of money to New Zealand runs in excess of $2 billion a year from New Zealanders working in Australia. There is very little flow the other way. Of course, with the deregulation of the banking system under Keating, we simply do not know how much money is leaving the country but, quite clearly, it is substantial. In the long run, I suppose we can be big brother to New Zealand: the problem is when governments want to make us big brother to the rest of the world. Let me now move to the amendment to the Moomba-Sydney pipeline legislation dealing with the transfer of easements. The Commonwealth maintained an interest in the pipeline easements primarily to ensure that other people could use the easements. The Commonwealth has now decided that the demand is not there but that it will enshrine guarantees for other people to use the easements. I think that is all very reasonable and sounds like common sense. I do not see how you can sell the residual share in the easements and, at the same time, enshrine provision for other parties, as yet unknown, to use these easements. Certainly, I do not know how you can do it without dramaticaIIy reducing the money that you were going to get from these easements. While I very strongly support other people having access to those easements at very reasonable costs, it is my experience that governments tend to like money so if the government can work that out it wilI be for the better. I want to talk a little about the treaty between Australia and the Republic of Indonesia in respect of the zone of cooperation. I was probably the instigator of the original Timor Gap treaty when I took Mr Brian Conway to see the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, BilI Hayden. The argument at the time was that Australia had made what could only be described as an enormous land grab--which would not have been upheld in any international court-by taking our land claim virtually to the border of Timor. It was my view that it would be much better if we could get an agreement with Indonesia for a mutual area where we could jointly exploit it. That course came to fruition. I believe that Bill Hayden deserves the credit for that and not Gareth Evans. Unfortunately, it is unlikely that history will be written that way. I have had a few letters from people claiming that Australia's sovereignty is being sold out. That is an absolute nonsense in this regard. I think it is being sold out every day in other respects but I believe the treaty signed with Indonesia on the use of the surrounding seas is in fact very much in Australia's favour. It must be said that the department has done a good job in this regard. I would like to mention the AQIS function. The government is here seeking to increase penalties for the introduction of sea organisms in the bilge water of ships. We have already seen such organisms introduced into Australia and it is an ever present threat to us. Even with this bilI, I am not sure that we are doing enough to ensure the security of our shores. There is a reasonably stiff penalty in there but I very much doubt that it can be policed adequately. I would like to see some better system of policing. I also point out that the demise of cabotage, and the entry of foreign ships into our coastal waters, is an additional threat to Australia. In the long run, we might see any short-term benefit in cost vastly outweighed by the threat to our environment. Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4757 I also find it a little unsettling to hear the member for Mayo( Mr Downer), the present Minister for Foreign Affairs, talking in the parliament today about our international commitments. One feels that there will be a tendency to water down all forms of protection under pressure from GAIT or our current masters in the United States, and I think that this is a very dangerous thing-if it is possible that quarantine measures are in fact a non-tariff protection measure. But it is my view that we cannot be too careful with quarantine measures. If we are seen by foreign countries as using this non-tariff protection measure, so be it. I would rather live with that than have the problems that we could inherit if we were to slacken our quarantine vigilance. This is a crucial point for Australia. One has really to consider the cost to us as a nation if, through laxity or mindless government adherence to some treaty that other nations tend to honour much more in the breach, we suffer losses in this regard. I tried to introduce into this parliament a private member's bill making the government responsible for such occurrences when industry suffers losses but, as a private member's bill, it did not go anywhere. I certainly think it would be incumbent upon the National Party, if it still represents rural Australia, to consider such a bill to make the government responsible for any mistakes that occur through laxity in our quarantine regulations. That is about all that can be said on the bill. It is mainly a bill which provides enabling mechanisms, and I guess it will be supported by both sides. to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1997 that the government has put forward, it is pleasing to hear that we have the support of the other side. We are debating this issue in the Main Committee, because it is non-controversial legislation. I will explain to the Main Committee some of the amendments, because our agricultural sector is obviously a very important industry not only from a jobs perspective but also from a national economy perspective. We have received some industry criticism in relation to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987 that the cost of participating in the Australian Horticultural Corporation, the AHC, is too high. I confirm to the Main Committee that the Australian Horticultural Corporation undertook a review of its overhead costs in relation to this criticism. As a means of reducing overheads, the AHC proposed a reduction in the size of the board membership from nine to seven and a reduction in remuneration for the board. The AHC is certainly aware of the criticism and is trying to address some of those concerns. I would like to point out that the Australian horticulture sector is an increasingly important sector to the agricultural and rural areas of Australia. Horticulture is already a major domestic agricultural industry but has a much lower export focus than that of most other agricultural industries. In 1995-96, Australia's horticulture industry had a gross production value of about $4.2 billion. The total value for fresh and processed horticultural produce in 1995-96 was over $1 billion. With changing consumer tastes, including a growing interest in health and lifestyle issues, there will be an increased demand for horticultural produce in the foreseeable future; hence the importance of the amendments to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1997. In relation to the Export Control Act 1992, the proposed amendments to section 23 will enable non-government persons specified by the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to issue certain certificates required for export. This will enhance administrative efficiency and ensure that the persons signing export documentation under

speaker: Mr Bruce Scott (Maranoa
theText: Minister for Veterans' Affairs) (4.42 p.m.)-In speaking4758 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 quality based arrangements can be properly regulated. These amendments will be used, for example, in the implementation of quality schemes in the horticulture industry-where it is proposed that certificates, such as certificates of condition requested by certain overseas governments, will be signed by company management-and in the organics industry, where it is proposed that industry associations issue organic produce certificates attesting to product quality. As I mentioned, with changing lifestyles and the increasing focus on healthy food, this is certainly also another step which will assist that industry in identifying and certifying the quality of the produce. The member for Kalgoorlie ( Mr Campbell) raised the issue of the changes to the Farm Household Support Act 1992 and the Social Security Act 1991. The Farm Household Support Act provides for overpayments of drought relief to be recovered as a debt due to the Commonwealth but does not specify the means by which these debts are to be recovered. The amendments will provide the mechanism by which drought relief payment debts can be recovered, thereby maintaining equity with other social security payments such as the newstart allowance. The proposed amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 will allow recovery of drought relief overpayments through a range of mechanisms that currently apply to specific social security payments not currently including drought relief payments. The drought relief payment has been an extremely invaluable source of money for families hard hit by drought. Of course, coming from a rural constituency that has been hit with five years of drought, I know just how welcome it has been for our farming constituencies. However, I know, and the farming constituencies know too, that we need a fair system and that where there has been an overpayment these moneys have to be recovered by the Commonwealth. These changes really will mean that the recovery mechanisms that will be made available include deductions from future drought relief payments or deductions from social security payments. I think they certainly agree with that process. It is about a fair system and the farming constituency acknowledging that the government is trying to help by making these arrangements as flexible as possible in relation to the recovery of those overpayments. The amendment to the Imported Food Control Act 1992 will enable Australia to fulfil our obligations in respect of the agreement reached with New Zealand that food safety and food standards are equivalent between the two countries. The amendment will allow for the Governor General to make regulations that give exemptions from the Imported Food Control Act for certain foods of New Zealand origin. This means that for public health concerns those foods will be treated as if produced here and subject to point of sale rather than point of entry inspection. This amendment has no effect on Australia's quarantine requirements or practices. There are also amendments in relation to the Moomba-Sydney Pipeline Systems Act 1994, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967, the Sea Installations Act 1987 and the Quarantine Act 1908. To refer to one other point raised by the member for Kalgoorlie in relation to the Sea Installations Act, he contended that the foreign ships participating on our coastal routes may be detrimental to our national interests. Let me assure the member for Kalgoorlie that that is not the case. I think he will find that when we get more competition on sea routes around our nation we will have a far more competitive environment, one which is far more conducive to making sure that our industries in Australia are internationally competitive. It will mean that we will be able to make the most of the opportunities that present themselves in the international markets. Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4759 I thank members from both sides of the House for their contribution to the debate on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2). Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Bill-by leave-reported to the House without amendment. Second Reading Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Mr Bruce Scott: That the bill be now read a second time. Amendment (Budget and Simplification Measures) Bill 1997 has two main elements. Firstly, it seeks to integrate into the social security system most child related payments to veterans' families. Secondly, it attempts to simplify the current rate calculation provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The plan to integrate into the social security system child related payments to service pensioners and income supplement recipients was announced in last year's federal budget. It seeks to ensure that from 1 January 1998 almost all child related payments will be the responsibility of the new Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency, which is due to take over the payment role of the Department of Social Security from JUly. The previous federal government inherited from the Fraser government a complex, poorly targeted and mean system of family payments. That system included family allowance, additional benefits for pensioners and beneficiaries, and the family income supplement for the working poor. Under the families package, these separate child related payments have been integrated into a single family payments system that is targeted towards lowand middle-income families. That recognises the additional costs of caring for older children or living in private rental accommodation. Just as importantly, the families package ensured that family payments to lowincome families were linked to a benchmark of adequacy that entailed indexation. In 1993, the Social Security Act was amended to integrate child related payments to pensioners into the family payments system. This bill seeks to achieve the same outcome for veterans' families with dependent children. The aim is to enable social security officers to become more of a one-stop shop for family payments, reducing the need for families to have dealings with separate agencies. If handled effectively, such an objective has much to commend it. To achieve this outcome, and with one important qualification, this bill effectively transfers responsibility for child related payments to veterans' affairs income support recipients from the Department of Veterans' Affairs to the social security family payments system. To ensure that no family will be worse off financially as a result of the change, the bill includes an important savings provision. This provision preserves the payment by Veterans' Affairs of child related payments such as the dependent child add-on, the pensioners full rent assistance, and the guardian allowance, where a pensioner or recipient would otherwise be

The opposition welcomes this safety net provision, which ensures that there will be no losers from the measure. The second major element of the bill seeks to simplify the present rate calculation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The two elements are linked because the transfer of child related payments to Social Security requires amendment of existing rate calculators. The current rate calculation provisions in the act extend to some 110 pages, and entail six separate rate calculators and nine separate method statements. If you were to believe the title of the media release issued by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs( Mr Bruce Scott) on 27 March 1997, it is a case of the minister cleaning up his act! Mr Bruce Scott-That is right. it should be noted that on the most optimistic assumptions this bill will probably reduce th865-page Veterans' Entitlements Act by a comparatively modest 80 pages. The minister's second reading speech indicates that this is the first instalment in a staggered review of the act to redraft it along 'plain English' lines. The opposition supports such a redraft and seeks clarification from the government of the timetable and process that are to be applied to the project, and the resources devoted to it in an environment where the department's staff levels continue to fall. Turning to the specifics of the rate calculators, there are at present six-one for each of the following categories: service pensioners with children; service pensioners without children; service pensioners who are blind; service pensioners on frozen rate; income support supplement recipients with children; and income support supplement recipients without children. The bill seeks to replace these separate calculators with a single rate calculator, but one that contains seven modules and involves six overall rate calculation processes, all of which largely mirror the existing processes. This highlights the complexity of this crucial aspect of the legislation, resulting from incremental decisions that have been made over the years to make exceptions of certain situations. I well understand thrJ in complex systems there often needs to be a trade-off between the objectives of simplicity and clarity, on the one hand, and equity and fairness on the other. As a result of changes to the rate calculators, the bill also introduces consequent changes to the Aged Care Act 1997 and the Aged Care Income Testing Act. These are simply housekeeping changes that make no change to existing entitlements. The opposition does not oppose the provisions of the bill dealing with the rate calculation process, but wishes to flag an anomaly or two that require attention by the government. A particular anomaly that has been brought to my attention by a range of veterans' groups concerns the impact of disability pension payments on rent assistance to service pensioners. This is something that is directly relevant to the rate calculation aspects of this bill. There is bipartisan agreement that disability pensions, being compensation for war caused injury or iIIness, should not be counted as income for taxation or veterans' affairs pension purposes. The only exception to this at present is that, under the act, where a service pensioner also receives a disability pension, the rate of their disability pension reduces the rate of rent assistance payable. Where the pensioner is receiving a high percentage of disability compensation, this can completely extinguish their access to rent assistance. theText: At the outset can I put in an apology in this4764 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 opposition's perspective, however, that we do not see any controversial elements contained in this bill, which at the end of the day simply changes in a whole variety of very minor ways the way in which this act operates. Accordingly, we will certainly not be opposing it and we do not, as I have said, suggest it is in any way controversial. This bill seeks to amend a number of acts administered under the portfolio responsibility of industry, science and tourism. The Australian Science and Technology Council Act of 1978 is amended to add the council's functions and to reflect the addition of the term 'engineering' to the name of the council. Appointments to this council will be made in future by the minister responsible, with the approval of the Prime Minister( Mr Howard), rather than the Governor General. The only thing I say about that is, of course, that we would like assurances, and I am sure the minister will be quite prepared to give them, that those appointments are from a carefully selected and culled group of individuals, that ministerial discretion reflects that the best possible people are appointed and that there are no other reasons why people should be appointed to that particular organisation. I will come back to the tourist commission in a moment. The National Measurement Act of 1960 is similarly amended, requiring the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to maintain, or cause to be maintained, coordinated universal time as determined by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures. The amendment will ensure that measurements are made on a consistent basis throughout the nation and are compatible with measurements in other countries. Again, this is a very sensible thing to do. The Science and Industry Research Act 1949 is to be amended to remove section 9AB from the act consistent with the current restructuring of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The Bounty (Machine Tools and Robots) Act 1985, the Coal Tariff Legislation Amendment Act 1992, the Patents, Trademarks, Designs and Copyright Act 1939, the Resource Assessment Commission Act 1989 and the Trade Marks Act 1995 are similarly to be amended to make a number of technical amendments in these pieces of legislation which are, again, non-controversial and therefore supported by the opposition. The Australian Tourist Commission Act 1987 is to be amended to remove the requirement that the members of the board of the commission cease to hold office at the age of 65 and that the board not employ persons on terms and conditions more favourable than those of the managing director, and that is probably a very sensible thing to do. Finally, the Australian Tourist Commission (Transitional Provisions) Act 1987 is to be repealed as it no longer has application. As I have indicated, Mr Deputy Speaker, the opposition does not oppose any of this legislation. However, in connection with the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1987, permit me to make some very brief comments generally about tourism which I seek your indulgence to do. In particular, what I am concerned about and what I think the Australian tourism industry is concerned about are the number of difficulties now being caused by some of the comments, some of the perceptions, and certainly by some of the newspaper reporting, of the activities of the One Nation Party and the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). A couple of weeks ago I was in Brisbane as part of my responsibility as the shadow minister for tourism and I met with a number of people from the Brisbane Chinese community. These were Hong Kong Chinese Australians and Taiwanese Chinese Australians and they raised with me their concerns-particularly from a tourism perspective-about the effect that the One Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4765 Nation Party's philosophies, and the comments being peddled by the member for Oxley, were having on tourism. This is in recognition of the fact that we are finding that the damaging debate in this country, with its racist overtones, is damaging our tourism industry. That is just one example. I therefore found it quite interesting that in the Sunday Telegraph, a Sydney newspaper, on I June this year, there was a comment piece by Sarah Harris under the heading of 'Passing the tourist buck'. I thought it was absolutely fascinating to read this. As you are a regional member from Victoria, Mr Deputy Speaker Reid, and I note also that there is a regional member from Queensland present, I think that this is an article to which your attention should be drawn. It talked about the operation of a Victorian tourism proposal and it said: In the northernmost tip of East Gippsland Shire there is a tiny community called Delegate River which-by virtue of the Victorian government's lack of appreciation-should rightfully belong to NSW. We will not quibble about that. The article goes on to say: It has a beauty so sharp that if God did not rest there on the seventh day, he must at least have dawdled a while to admire his handiwork. Sarah Harris goes on to say: Late last year, this community was buzzing with the prospect of the first of several convoys of visitors from Singapore. But at the height of the so-called race debate, the bookings were cancelled. It has taken much work by local operators to rekindle the Singaporeans' interest. This month, the Delegate River Tavern and Tranquil Valley Resort will accommodate at least 20 visitors from Singapore. Their hostess, Val Savige, has already received plenty of well-meaning-if mistaken-advice from local patrons. "They will only eat raw fish,' warned one regular. "They don't like being touched on the head," advised another. The colourful local bard, minus his two front teeth, has kindly offered to take them fishing. They may also meet a man rumoured, in a passion of grief, to have consumed the ashes of his late wife, or be privileged enough to see a platypus playing in the creek below their cabins. They may learn that Kentucky Fried Chicken is local parlance not for fast food but Department of Community Services officers who "take-away kids". But whatever their tourists do, they will experience the genuine warmth of a real Australian community populated by characters as endearing as they are individual. This is the best antidote we've got to Pauline Hanson's venom. 4766 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 I think that particular article demonstrated that in rural communities in Victoria-just as is the case in what are commonly described as popular tourist destinations in this country, like tropical Queensland, the Gold Coast, Sydney, and so on-some of the nonsense that has been peddled by people and has been reflected, regrettably, in newspapers in Asia is having a detrimental effect on the Australian tourism industry. that that article was printed in and the date? concluding my remarks in this debate, I again want to make it perfectly clear to people in this country associated with the Australian Tourist Commission and the Australian tourism industry, and more generally to our colleagues on both sides of this parliament, that there are real and lasting factors that, regrettably, are going to be a great disadvantage to Australia's tourism industry in some of this debate. The amendments in the Industry, Science and Tourism Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 are, in themselves, not important but they give me an opportunity to say something which I think is perhaps fundamental. The fact that they are brought together from various parts of legislation, affecting various areas of government responsibility but all coming under the minister for industry, is very pertinent. It is about time we started to understand what we mean by industry and industry policy. Rod Cameron of ANOP made a very interesting speech last week to the minerals conference in Canberra, in which he pointed out that the current assessment that he has made of his own work and some work on behalf of the minerals industry suggests that people in Australia are extremely concerned about the perceived absence of industry policy. In the chamber, day after day we have been debating these questions about industry policy. It is important to start talking about what that actually means. There are some who think industry policy is a way of giving cash or some handout to business. There are some who think that one writes a monumental manuscript of enormous length and detail, spelling out how every industry should work. The Prime Minister( Mr Howard), in some smart remark the other day, referred to a 1O-year plan. A lot of people feel that somehow there has to be a single, discrete thing: complex, detailed, and totally prescriptive. Perhaps one day it may be that; I have never known it to be. Industry policy in a modem Western society is the accretion of a whole range of forces: many negative, many positive. It also involves a mind-set and an understanding of what industry is actually about. The idea that taking away the regulations, taking away government and taking away so-called red tape and letting business get on with being in business will somehow produce some coherence is-quite frankly-fanciful. The idea that out of chaos comes order is not very logical. An industry policy first requires an understanding of what the drivers are and what the forces at work are. The forces include competition, government, cost, innovation, commitment, and an understanding of how the bits fit together-how the ingredients actually work together.

As all members know, the Industry, Science and Tourism Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 amends a number of acts administered by the portfolio of industry, science and tourism. As has been acknowledged by one speaker after another, the changes are not controversial and are mostly technical in nature. Several of the proposed amendments implement important election commitments given by the government in the area of science, engineering and technology. For example, we have maintained our commitment before the last election to change the name of the Australian Science and Technology Council to become the Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council-a very important and symbolic change which has been welcomed by the Institution of Engineers and by the engineering community in general. The Australian Science, Technology and Engineering Council is a very significant source of independent advice on science, engineering and technology policy. The amendments to the Australian Science and Technology Council Act 1978 implement this important name change. The government has also sought to implement a number of changes to improve the effectiveness of the CSIRO, consistent with our recognition of that research body having a leading role in Australia's technology and industry development. Overcoming structural impediments to focus on key research products was a primary concern. Changes proposed to the Science and Industry Research Act 1949 reflect the new administrative framework developed by the review of CSIRO's management structure and performance, and put in place the government's objective to facilitate greater flexibility in CSIRO's structures and research programs. I am glad to say that that new structure is working particularly well. The remaining amendments are largely administrative in nature and, as such, do not raise substantive issues. speaker: Mr Mcgauran (Gippsland
theText: Minister for Science and Technology) (5.30 p.m.)-I am4770 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 Second Reading Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Mr Ruddock: That the bill be now read a second time. in the Spicer review into the migration agents registration scheme. One key finding says: ... in the absence of regulation, the market for migration advice has tended to operate imperfectly with consumers bearing unacceptable cost in terms of exploitation and inappropriate practice by a sector of the industry; ... More importantly, another key finding says: ... that the Scheme has provided a measure of consumer protection and ... its credibility as a consumer protection mechanism has strengthened somewhat in the time since the Joint Standing Committee on Migration (JSCM) conducted a review of the Scheme; ... Essentially, there is an admission out there that this is one industry that needs a significant amount of regulation. I would be the first to admit that the organisation that, in the long term, the government sees as having some role in self-regulation-the Migration Institute of Australia-is a reasonably reputable association. It has structured meetings with the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs three times a year; it has conducted training courses; it was involved in the Roach inquiry; and, indeed, it is an organisation that we do not have too many criticisms of. It has even received grants from the government to develop a practical training course. The reality, as the other part of the quote says, is that there is an industry here in which we see very desperate people and we see some very crude sharks in the market who very much are on the ball essentially to exploit these people, whether by claiming refugee status when they have got no bona fides in the world, by launching spouse or de facto relationships when people have not even got the required cohabitation, by having people already in bigamous relations purporting to remarry et cetera-you go along the train of claims. Many times it is essentially aimed at buying time in Australia, once they come here and overstay, to develop a relation-hip with somebody during their period of fighting this refugee claim. I want to say, on the other hand, that, whilst there is a need to supervise those kinds of operators in this industry, the reality of life is that you often have people in your electorate, constituents, who have been just as involved in this conspiracy. They want to buy time, they want to rort the Australian system and they are out here to overstay. The inquiry, titled Protecting the vulnerable, by a joint committee of which the current minister was a member, came down in favour of a number of recommendations. They included the continuation of the then scheme for three years, a review at the end of that period, continued registration of lawyers-which was a fairly controversial measure and which was upheld in the courts of this country, despite the views of lawyers-individuals not being required to register if they worked for voluntary organisations and training modules for migration agents. It also suggested something which this government should do, and which was suggested to the previous government; and that is to close the long standing loophole that advice to sponsors and nominators is not covered by the provisions of legislation. As I say, it should have been undertaken by the previous government and it is more than necessary to be undertaken today

speaker: Mr Laurie Ferguson (Reid) (5.34 P.m.)
theText: There are a number of telling commentsTuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4771 because it is a major loophole where those who are in malpractice in this field ignore the needs. That unanimous inquiry, which wrote to all 1,450 then registered agents, received 65 submissions, had witnesses from major sectors of the industry, such as the department, the Ethnic Communities Council of New South Wales, immigration advice centres, the Law Council, the Migration Agents Registration Board and so on, and came to a number of conclusions. Amongst them were the following: The principal issue is not whether the advice is paid for or is provided free of charge, but whether consumers, particularly those who are least able to shop around for advice, should be able to expect accurate advice from competent advisers, and whether they should be able to access appropriate avenues of redress should the advice which is provided prove to be negligent, inaccurate or dishonest. The committee furthermore, at XXVI, noted: One particularly invidious outcomeand I have just mentioned itof the omissionthat is, of nominators and sponsorsis that persons who have been found to be unqualified or unfit to practise as migration agents can circumvent the scheme by directing their practice through sponsors. The parliamentary committee furthermore noted at 2.20, on page 9: In addition to the above, many requests for immigration advice arise from persons who are not in a position to advance adequately their own cases or the cases of family members. Applicants may lack an adequate command of English, or may not comprehend the requirements for making immigration applications. Such applicants may be unable or unclear about how to best advance their cases. Applicants from different cultural backgrounds might not understand the processes and the statutory requirements relating to visa applications. At 3.82 the committee came to a unanimous summary of the then prevailing situation in the industry and in the regulation of those agents. It noted at page 61: Statistics obtained by the Committee support a finding that achievements of the Scheme relevant to its objectives have been chequered. On the positive side, around 600 persons either have been denied the right to practise as migration agents or have decided to withdraw from seeking entry to the industry. In addition, the avenues for developing expertise in migration law have increased noticeably, with various courses and seminars now being conducted at a tertiary level and within the industry itself. On the negative side, disciplinary action taken against migration agents has been minimal, even though the number of complaints in relation to registered and unregistered practice has been increasing over time. I want to put on the record at this stage that that is certainly a very clear weakness of the current scheme. There are doubts out there as to the way in which people can be pursued and, I guess, an unwillingness by many people exploited to come forward because of the reality of their situation. I have got to express some early doubts that self-regulation is going to essentially do anything about that aspect-the most significant aspect of the problem. We might be able to bemoan the question of cost to the users in the field, we might be able to make a number of other criticisms of the scheme as it currently operates but, fundamentally, I believe the most important aspect of this is to rid the industry of these people, dissuade them from participation and, whether people like to hear this or not, penalise them and throw them out of the industry if necessary. I do not think that that most crucial aspect of the problem that the committee itself noted is going to be tackled by self-regulation. 4772 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 There is an admission by the Spicer inquiry-and this is why we have got a situation here today where the legislation is being extended until next year-that the industry's main organisation, which I have earlier indicated is one which we can largely have respect for, is not in a situation where it can claim to be representative of the industry. Its membership is rather small. I think the last figure was 2,200 people registered. There are some major players that are members of the Migration Institute of Australia. There is talk about banks, even voluntary organisations and corporations, and there are probably some practices in this field which are members, but a significant part of the industry is not involved in the institute. The Spicer inquiry says that at this stage it is incapable of policing the industry. That is why the government speaks about the concept of statutory self-regulation as an interim measure in their move towards self-regulation. The minister notes agreement with this analysis of where they are at but, on our side of the debate, we do not have the confidence that he has that the ability might be there within the next six months. are, as he says, incapable at this stage of conducting self-regulation-and I take his point. The situation, as the Spicer inquiry noted, is such that there are quite a few remaining problems in the field. As a person who has consistently questioned the degree of influence of various lobby groups on our migration policy, I want to say that I think we went to the other extreme in the Spicer inquiry. I notice that one of the members of the inquiry had some involvement with Careforce, but I thought the balance was too far in the other direction if we look at the membership; it had a significant preponderance of practitioners. At the end of the day, regardless of one's analysis of them as individuals, you would have to ask whether there was a degree of self-interest in moving the government out of the field, moving the administration out of the field and thrusting towards self-regulation. I am not saying for a moment that there are particular errors or particular weaknesses in the inquiry but, as I say, I think I have a reasonable track record in not wanting these kinds of organisations to be dominated by FECCA or by some immigration advice centre. But, if one were to analyse the make-up, one would perhaps say it had swung too far in another direction. The inquiry did make a few pertinent points that are important for the future, regardless of whether there is support eventually for self-regulation. I think its point No. 11, on page 5, is accurate and should be taken on board regardless of the direction this country goes in. It notes: ... there has been inadequate promotion of the current Scheme and, in whatever arrangement replaces the current Schemeor, for that matter, if the current scheme continuesan ongoing consumer information strategy, targeted in particular to members of non-English speaking background communities, needs to be developed. That is indicative of what I said earlier. I think there is a lack of knowledge out there of what to do if people feel that they have been ripped off or even if the people they go to feel ripped off. There is a lack of knowledge and a lack of confidence perhaps that, at the end of the road, they will be getting success in pursuing people. The Spicer inquiry also noted: that in a deregulated environment, consumers in the migration advice industry would not be able to rely solely on the remedies available to them under consumer protection legislation and have in fact failed

speaker: Mr Laurie Ferguson
theText: Sorry, 20 years time, is it? The minister is conceding that theyTuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4773 to take action to any significant extent either in the courts under the consumer protection provisions of trade practices legislation or in the States and Territories small claims tribunals. So they are putting on the record something that is in evidence: that there is a relative lack of successful prosecutions, and many people-as we noted earlier-have been dissuaded from moving into the industry. But that does not mean that there are still not a number of people who perhaps, with more knowledge in the field and with more determination, might have been pursued. We have concerns that with a reduction in the support of various advice centres by the government in the 1996 budget, these people that we are supposedly trying to tackle and supervise and to rid ourselves and the industry of, are going to be encouraged. There is no doubt that the significant reduction in support by the government of people who are doing this kind of assistance on a voluntary basis only opens up the field in a more obvious way to those who wish to exploit people. The legislation, as on a previous occasion, is an extension by this government of the currently operating provisions. AndI want to mention again that unanimous report, Protecting the vulnerable? which made a number of significant suggestions as to the better operation of the supervisory section of the industry. Some of those suggestions were not taken up by the previous government; others which were taken up, in the view of the Spicer inquiry, essentially improved the situation. The summary position is that we do have here a field that allows people who have come from societies where there are repressive regimes lacking the rule of law, where people have no knowledge of the court system, where they have fears of police and of police institutions, to feel more confident. We are saying to these people that they should know their rights straight away. They should know that they have to be very thorough ir. the way they deal with people offering advice to them. That is not the reality that people have out there. They are extremely desperate on many occasions and see their only option as being the person they have been led to by family or friends or, more often, that person who advertises very heavily in particular ethnic media and who sometimes has the support of institutions within the ethnic community as being their basic salvation and way of staying in this country. They are, as the opposition notes, very vulnerable and they should be our primary responsibility and we should not adopt an attitude as to how we should regulate this industry on the basis of ideological bent. We should have doubts about an industry which, at this stage at least, in the view of the Spicer inquiry is not capable of operating without very major improvement. It should get more people involved, have more membership, and reach a stage when it really can say that it represents the industry. Until that happens, I think that we have really got to question whether the next stage of this process is in the interests of those people that we say are most vulnerable. One of the recommendations of the Spicer review stated: ... in the interests of developing a cohesive industry with consistent standards, mandatory registration as migration agents continue to apply to legal practitioners. That is an important point that the joint committee in its past review strongly supported, regardless of their feelings of self-importance and their desire not to be covered by regulation. The other point that the opposition would have some concerns about is the resourcing of this regulation. It is not just a question of eventually handing it over and being hopeful that things will basically scrabble through and that they will be able to do it through their own 4774 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 resources. The opposition supports the extension of the current legislation, believing that, on bal;mce, it has had major accomplishments, that it has kept a lot of people out of the industry whu should not have been in it in the first place. The legislation has had some measure of supervisory oversight so that perhaps people will be more reluctant to exploit others. It has probably accomplished that in the area of fears about moving the charges too heavily. It has, in some cases, removed people from the industry and essentially, at the end of the day, it has a motivation which is beyond the self-interest of those people who seek-supposedly in the long-term-to regulate themselves. I commend the bill. 3) 1997 provides for a six-month extension to the migration agents registration scheme under the Migration Act 1958, given that the present six-month sunset clause would see the scheme terminate on 21 September this year. Extending the scheme to 21 March 1998 will initially allow for the introduction of statutory self-regulation as a transition stage before the eventual introduction of full self-regulation. The Migration Institute of Australia, a relatively new industry body, will have time to establish the necessary structures to take on this self-regulatory role of over 2,200 migration agents now operating. Disciplinary sanctions including removal of the right to practise are expected to form part of the industry based self-regulation. There will also be specific complaints resolution processes to protect vulnerable members of our community and aspirant members who use migration agents. The government's plan to move progressively from the current scheme to partial supervised deregulation and eventually to industry self-regulation will enable the government to support and work with reputable agents and allow this peak body to develop standards and selfregulatory systems and procedures, picking up on the comments of the member for Reid( Mr Laurie Ferguson). Two years ago, the Joint Standing Committee on Migration in its report Protecting the vulnerable? delivered some mixed findings on the operation of the scheme which had only been established in September 1992. When the then government introduced the scheme, they rejected self-regulation because of a claimed high level of fragmentation in the industry. The creation of an industry peak body since then is an important step in ensuring that migration agents are more able to speak with one voice. I found it interesting that the joint standing committee's report suggested that it was difficult to determine just how many visa applicants sought the advice of migration agents. An Immigration Rights and Advice Centre telephone survey suggested that three per cent of callers specifically sought guidance on alleged wrong advice or the checking of other advice from migration agents. However, the complexity of migration legislation and regulation, the extent to which people compete for places, and an applicant's inability to advance their own or their family's case are other factors pushing them towards migration agents. The joint standing committee criticised the generally low level of public awareness of the scheme, as has been mentioned by the member for Reid. The scheme has also not fulfilled its aim of becoming self-funding. On a more positive note, the committee noted that 600 people had been stopped from practising as migration agents. This demonstrates that the provision of migration advice is an imperfect market and that the current regulatory system still enabled shonks to get a foothold in some cases. speaker: Mr Billson (Dunkley) (5.51 P.m.)
theText: The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4775 more than legal nonsense.' The Immigration Review Tribunal commented that in 1993-94 the proportion of successful applicants was the same, whether or not a professional adviser was used. The self-regulatory regime will bring forward the self-interest of reputable agents to ensure that vulnerable potential migrants are not exposed to incompetence, dishonest and exploitative practices from people offering migration advice to the discredit of legitimate, competent and qualified professionals working in the field. Last time. I spoke on this subject, I suggested that migration agents were people who were proffers of hope. They sold the hope and the prospects of coming to our country as a key ware that they had to offer for their payments. That just highlights the importance of protecting people who tum to these advisers in the hope that they will improve their prospects and chances of migrating to our great country. The proposed changes in the bill follow an internal review by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. The task force took advice from a group of independent experts chaired by Mr Ian Spicer, former chair of the Australian Chamber of Commerce. One recent example brought to my attention is of a visitor to Australia who liked the place so much he wanted to stay. He must have been visiting the electorate of Dunkley; it is a wonderful place. A migration adviser in a regional centre, which I will not mention-not far from Dunkley-advised him to apply as a refugee. He said that he was not a refugee in any sense of the word, but he followed the advice he had been provided for his $3,000. Clearly, he was rejected and now forfeits any credibility when applying in the future on more legitimate grounds. I cannot begin to tell you how much he laments taking the advice that was offered to him. It also leads to the question of lawyers, and I am pleased to see that lawyers are being brought within the scope of the program. It is not a question about whether they are charging more than $1.20 per photocopy page or those sorts of things. It is an important specialist area where very much they are providing advice on hope. Just as migration agents need to ensure that they understand the program, so must lawyers. Going back to that earlier comment, pure legal nonsense is not a way of getting through the system, notwithstanding the considerable sums of money that are often paid for very poor advice. I am sure the member for Reid and other colleagues in the committee room are aware of the number of people coming into electorate offices all around the country looking for help after they have paid good money to migration agents only to find that they have sent them up the wrong track. I am very encouraged by what the minister is doing and I would like to pick up on some of the points that the member for Reid has mentioned. We seem to be in heated agreement over this. We seem to agree that there are doubts over whether the present system as it is is working effectively. We share that view, and we also share the view that the current system has been inadequately promoted and that there is a lack of knowledge about it. Unlike the member for Reid, I do not believe there are doubts over self-regulation at this time because of the way the minister is going about this particular transition. What he is saying in the first instance is, 'We'll supervise a partial self-regulation, where the minister can delegate the authorities to the institute, and see how it goes.' We can learn from the experience. The minister is there to provide advice and support over time as the instituteagain as the member for Reid says-develops and matures and gets up to speed to be a fully competent peak body for the industry. 4776 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 It is interesting that the member for Reid referred to some papers on the free advice that is provided to people seeking to migrate to Australia. My view is that, wherever you are getting your advice from, the consumer still deserves protection. I certainly would encourage the minister and the institute to consider including voluntary organisation in the work of the institute as we move into this partial self-regulation regime. The reason I say that is that I have many people coming to my electorate office seeking our assistance after they have spoken with an ethnic community organisation outlining perhaps how they should go about seeking to apply to enter our country. Often that advice is not accurate. Often that advice has led to people from my part of the world being very up-beat and very positive about their prospects without really seeing how they measure up against the criteria of the migration program. In some way, I would certainly encourage the minister to ask the Migration Institute of Australia to take in some of those organisations, both in the development phase of the systems and procedures that it is putting in place in preparation for self-regulation and also to see whether there is a way of ensuring that those community organisations, and others offering free advice--out of goodwill more than anything-are at least fully informed of what is going on and are not providing false hope to people. It also would ensure that the consumers that we are seeking to protect can be involved in the development of those systems and procedures as, once again referring to the member for Reid's comments, the institute gets up to speed in preparation for self-regulation. I will not add a lot more than that, although I did have some rather interesting facts on the changes that the government has made to the migration program, why I believe the changes are very much for the better, and why I believe the measures the government has put in place have built confidence in the migration program and, to some degree, have made it a little more complex, thereby increasing the need for competent advice to people wishing to apply. In closing, it is clear to me from reading this report and from my very vague understanding of the career of the member for Reid in this place that he has something to offer. I certainly encourage him to put forward his ideas and to make a positive contribution to what the minister is trying to achieve. He should let the Australian public and aspiring Australians benefit from the obvious understanding and insight he has on this subject. The opportunity is there in this supervised delegated regime that the minister is overseeing to ensure that the particular systems and processes, the checks and balances that need to be put in place, are developed and are in place as we move towards industry self-regulation. I commend the bill to the House, congratulate the minister on his continuing good work in a difficult place, and invite my colleagues on both sides of the House-including the boisterous member for Reid-to make a contribution where possible to the development of a selfregulatory system. 3) 1997 extends to 21 March 1998 the sunset clause of the migration agents registration scheme, which was to terminate on 21 September 1997 after having operated for five years. It is for that reason that the opposition supports this bill, and for that reason only. This move is in preparation, from the government's point of view, for statutory selfregulation for a transitional period, with a proposed move to full self-regulation of the migration agents industry. speaker: Mr Darga Vel (Fraser) (6.01 P.m.)
theText: The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4777 the blood bank to Dracula to look after. Unfortunately, Australia has seen some disappointing results from self-regulation. The opposition recognises the limitations that exist in a globalised market whereby migration agents who operate solely offshore are not subject to regulation in the same way that Australian-operating migrant agents are. However, we also need to recognise the inherent contradictions and limitations that self-regulation imposes, particularly in a market that even Mr Spicer has described as less than perfect. Mr Spicer is not known, from my experience, as someone who is an ardent opponent of selfregulation-indeed, he has often been at the forefront of running arguments supporting selfregulation. In this instance, he is encouraging us to be fairly cautious, and I think that is the prudent course for those who support self-regulation. For my part, I have some very serious concerns about the proponents of self-regulation in this industry in particular. For instance, the government has articulated concerns about the potential for abuse of the spouse provisions of the migration regulations. In fact, these concerns have been cited as justification for cuts to the migration program. This bill raises questions about how, at the end of the day, the government will be able to control the level of fraud in the marriage program, for example. If the government is really serious about stopping fraud in the marriage categories of the migration program, it would need to ensure that the method of regulation-self-regulation or otherwise-is effective, not only on the fraud issue but-and from my point of view this is a more important issue-the level of the exploitation of the applicants involved. One view is that, because of the complexity of migration law, it is unrealistic not to give applicants the ability to obtain professional advice about how to maximise their chances of lodging a successful migration application. The previous speaker suggested that voluntary organisations should be included in the scope of the current debate, but the facts of life are that they are already covered by the scope of the current regime. They already have competency standards and they compare very favourably with private providers. However, in the absence of adequate funding being provided so that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs can perform that function-and I note that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has sustained pretty tough cuts this round-the government needs to ensure that whatever regulatory regime is imposed or is adopted, whether it is self-regulation or otherwise, is effective. This arises essentially out of the complexity of migration law. We have accepted in this debate, prima facie, that migration law has to be complex and we have then progressed down the road about how migration advice may be provided. I suggest there is another course which bears some thought and that is the degree of complexity that migration law actually requires. The cost of migration applications is very high. There is the cost of applications, and a person may require further advice about migration law from migration agents. We need to really ensure that people are getting value for money in terms of accurate and lawful advice from migration agents and that that advice is fair dinkum. More importantly, we need to ensure that people who apply for migration to Australia do not have their expectations falsely raised about their chances of lodging a successful application, bearing in mind that this is an industry where people make profits out of other people's hopes and expectations. 4778 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 I have heard stories recounted today, which are consistent with this line of argument, of examples of genuine asylum seekers to this country who provide vast sums of money to agents in order to lodge applications for refugee status. Many of these people appear to have been told by unscrupulous agents that their claims will have a greater chance of success if they enter Australia through the back door, that is, come to Australia as a tourist and then lodge a claim 'for refugee status whilst in Australia. Someone who is desperate to escape an oppressive regime does not always have the time or inclination, capacity or resources, to sit down with immigration officials to determine the best way of proceeding. In these cases we need to ensure that asylum seekers do not arrive with false expectations of their claims being recognised simply because they have been encouraged to put up a large sum of money. Members might remember that I spoke yesterday of the problems encountered by workers on the Mandir Society'S temple which was opened in Canberra last weekend. I commented in the media last Sunday on this situation where workers are brought into the country and their rights as workers are breached. In that instance the workers were paid an appalling rate of 51 c an hour, contrary to the undertakings that the sponsor made to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. They were not paid superannuation, they were not paid proper allowances, they had inadequate safety protection, there was inadequate fall protection, if any, and there were no first aid kits on site, and so on and so on. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs was advised, but the sponsor was able to bring out more workers. The department allowed this circumstance to take place even though it knew that this blatant exploitation was taking place, Clearly, there needs to be a little bit more guts applied in some of these circumstances. I do not know whether, in that particular case, the workers were brought out through a migration agent, but that is not the point. In conclusion, the opposition supports the continuation of the current program, which is why we are supporting this bill. In terms of the debate about the progress to self-regulation, I think there are a number of matters and issues that still need to be resolved. I commend the bill to the House. p.m.)-in reply-I am pleased to have this opportunity to sum up in relation to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.3) 1997. I thank the members for Reid( Mr Laurie Ferguson), Dunkley( Mr Billson) and Fraser( Mr Dargavel) for their comments. As the member for Reid has left, I will come back to his remarks. I will pick up those of the honourable member for Fraser instead, in case he intends to leave. Let me deal with the issue on which I interjected, because it is a very important question. I am sorry if I missed some remarks you made yesterday in relation to this matter. It is the usual practice, if you wish ministers to be aware of your remarks, to indicate-perhaps by a call to the office-that you intend to raise something and then they might be in a position to follow it up quickly with you. Being now apprised of your remarks, I will have a look at the question. Let me also say that I have spoken with the construction union on a number of occasions during my consultations. While general issues have been raised with me about the need for efficacy in processing skilled applicants, either through employer nomination or under the other alternative arrangements which we have where there are tripartite labour market agreements for people to be able to enter Australia to work in particular situations, I understand the union's reticence and desire to protect conditions and so on. We are not about using the migration program as a basis for undermining conditions here in Australia. AllI would say is that at no point in time was I aware of the particular claims that you have raised in relation to the temple development here in Canberra. I do not recall that matter having ever been brought to my attention and, I suspect, if it had been, it would have been something that I would have noted. I simply make the point that my department is in a position to act in relation to visas granted on particular conditions, if we are apprised of the fact that breaches are occurring. There are certain natural justice provisions that have to be followed, and you do need to put before people the assertions that are made; and people need to stand up and say that somebody is not being properly paid, so that we can put those matters properly before them and deal with them. The reason that we have to follow that course is very simple: it is because of the administrative law that operates in this country. In relation to the rights that people obtain through the issue of a visa, we are not in a position to simply terminate the visa without following the natural justice principles of putting allegations that are made before people, for them to have an opportunity to correct them if an error has been made. speaker: Mr Ruddock (Berowra
theText: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs) (6.114780 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 regulations. I do not think it is generally understood why we have an act that is so complex and so difficultunderstanding of it. I do not know that that is necessarily desirable-not that I should have an understanding but that I should be the only one who understands it. I have an understanding of how this arose under your predecessors. Senator Ray was the person who essentially got in place the present act and regulatory regime. This was modified through the reform act that followed. We moved to introduce the statutory scheme that we have in place today because we had seen develop over time a situation where the previous largely discretionary regime was no longer capable of operating in this area. This was largely because of the operations of administrative law. The courts had essentially taken over the determination as to who was going to enter Australia and who was not. I frequently draw to people's attention and put before them an interesting article written by a former immigration official, Evan Arthur. He made it clear that we were going to have 14,000 onshore applications on strong and compelling compassionate grounds under the guidelines that have been developed for interpreting that provision, which was section 6A(l)(e) of the old migration act, by the courts when the matter was largely left for them to define what those words meant. The former government was not of the view that the immigration program should be dominated by people who had entered Australia on the pretext of being a visitor, simply managed to run a reasonably good story and then been able to stay in Australia. The view was that if people wanted to apply to come here they should apply offshore and wait their tum. Ultimately the statutory regime we had with the very limited discretion that ministers now have-the non-compellable discretion-was to ensure that the government of the day was able to administer the program as it had planned. You made some observations about asylum seekers. I would like to say that it is a vexed issue about which I could speak at length. I am certainly concerned to contain the abuse that is occurring in relation to asylum claims but I do so in the context of a determination to ensure that no bona fide refugee should be rejected. I recognise that some people's circumstances might be such that they will go to extraordinary lengths to get here. They will pay people. They will forge documents. They will mislead me as to their intentions. But it is because of their vulnerable situation and the claims have to be examined on that basis. That is the obligation we have accepted. My officials understand that and that is why we provide the opportunity for review independently by the Refugee Review Tribunal. I challenge the members of the Labor Party in relation to some of the proposed changes that I will be initiating during the course of these parliamentary sittings in relation to the issue of judicial review. We have already a very significant litigious load. I am probably the most sued minister of the Commonwealth at the present time. There was an expectation that when we put in place independent merits review that people would get out of the courts. It has not happened. The fact that the courts are involved has led to significant changes in the way in which people are able to enter Australia. It has removed a lot of the decision making from the

theText: So they can let you manage it, Minister.

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: It gives me an advantage over many. I at least have some element ofTuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4781 government of the day. I will be proposing a mechanism whereby we can again get control of the immigration program for the parliament and for the government of the day. That will be done through a privative clause which will ensure that the only matter that the courts will be able to examine is whether or not the people who take the decisions-at first instance, my department and the merits review system that we have in place-are legally competent to take the decision. That will considerably narrow the range of issues that we take into the courts and upon which the courts can tum their very creative minds. It will lead to a situation where the act may not have to go through the many contortions that it now goes through to deal with some of the very elaborate approaches that are taken by the courts in dealing with this act in particular cases. To come back to the bill that we are dealing with, the bill is to extend the sunset clause. If the sunset clause is not extended, the present statutory scheme collapses. Let us understand it-it collapses and then there will be no scheme. We are proposing an alternative; one that has been developed as a result of a review undertaken by my department; one that was the subject of advice from a reference group of very eminent Australians. I accept the comment of the honourable member for Fraser( Mr Dargavel) that Ian Spicer was a person who normally would be a gung-ho deregulator. He was a member of the reference group. Other members of the group included Pamela O'Neil, a former member of the Labor Party and a very distinguished agent for the Commonwealth in a variety of roles; Ian Tonking, a Sydney barrister and a specialist in trade practices matters, particularly in relation to consumer affairs issues; and Cheryl Webster. The member for Reid( Mr Laurie Ferguson) asked some questions about Cheryl Webster. I have known Cheryl over a long period of time. She works as a grant-in-aid worker for Careforce, which is part of the Anglican Home Mission. I do not think that in any way disqualifies her. Madam Deputy Speaker, the Anglican Home Mission society has worked amongst migrants and refugees in your electorate over a long period of time. Cheryl is a person of great personal quality and one who can contribute and did contribute significantly in relation to this. The other members of the group are John Hodges, a former minister, and Pauline Matthewson, a prominent member of the Migration Institute of Australia. It was a very balanced group and its advice was very helpful. It was not an ideological issue. It was a matter of addressing the work of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. The honourable member for Reid took us through the committee's report very helpfully, but I remind the member that I was on that committee and I am very much aware of its recommendations. The committee was of the view that self-regulation should be looked at. The reason that there was a sunset clause and it was continued was that this was an option that was always to be kept open. The committee recommended in 1995 that the migration agents registration scheme should continue to operate for another three years with a range of improvements, and that at that stage it should be reviewed so we could look at these further models. Self-regulation was one of those that was held out. We are operating largely within that time frame. It is important to recognise that what we are proposing is a form of regulatory selfregulation. In other words, there will be amendments to the act to establish that the Migration Institute is the body that will be undertaking the supervisory role. It will be in accordance with 4782 MAIN COMMITIEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 its code of ethics. It will administer a scheme in which peer pressure will establish, hopefully, the highest order of supervision and standards for membership. I think those people who are ethical and who are involved in the Migration Institute will be anxious to ensure that the higher standards are upheld. My expectation is that they will work with legal practitioners. They have already indicated to me that they will sit down with the Law Council to look at ways and means of integrating their different approaches to the question of supervision. I expect that they will be able to work together in the way in which this particular scheme is developed. I thank particularly my colleague the honourable member for Dunkley( Mr Billson) for his very supportive observations. I think they were far too generous, and I speak with a degree of experience in relation to that. I know my own weaknesses but I nevertheless thank him for it. Let me say that voluntary organisations will be included in the regime. We fund a number of organisations now for the purposes of providing advice, and that is important. We expect that those people who are offering free advice through voluntary agencies ought to be the subject of supervisory arrangements. They will still be able to be registered. They will not have to pay a fee and they will not have to necessarily satisfy the same comprehensive knowledge test. One of the things that I am very supportive of is the work that is undertaken through our universities and through a number of the voluntary organisations that we fund to provide tuition, if one might put it in that form, for people who want to be migration agents. We have a number of programs now that are leading to a better trained work force in this area. That applies not only to agents but to the legal profession. It is an area of some complexity and difficulty, and one where specialisation is very important today. I thank honourable members for their support for this legislation. Obviously, my officials and I will take on board all of the comments that have been made. We are in the process of drafting the legislation now and obviously there may be a much more comprehensive and vigorous debate when we see the substantive legislation.
