I spoke about it as being a humanising and responsive change so that people's real lives could be better integrated with the systems and procedures of the Child Support Agency. This is achieved by providing an opportunity for income estimate elections to better reflect the non-custodial parent's capacity to pay and, as a result, to reduce the likelihood of custodial parents having to refund overpayments. It will reward reliable payers of child support by allowing for their employers not to be involved in the arrangements where they have a satisfactory track record of paying. It also provides for the Family Court to take into account private arrangements amicably entered into when making property and spousal maintenance orders. I spoke about the bill as being a welcome first step in ensuring that the law supports and encourages the sort of desirable behaviour we hope for where a relationship is no longer viable and there are children left behind who need to be cared for. I mentioned a number of further reforms that I believe warrant consideration, and I sought to encourage the member for Werriwa( Mr Latham) and the member for Hunter( Mr Fitzgibbon) to constructively contribute to the diligent work that many of us in this place, under the chairmanship of the member for Grey( Mr Wakelin), are doing in trying to deal with many of the challenges facing the community, involving relationship breakdown and the care of kids. I say to those opposite: resist the temptation to be petty and pathetic as the coalition government seeks to deal with the recommendations that remain from the joint select committee report on the child support scheme and other, quite numerous, constructive ideas that have been brought forward by the coalition members working in conjunction with the member for Grey. I say that for the kids' sake. This is about making sure that the kids get the support, care and input from willing parents towards their development into young Australians and great citizens of this nation. There are a number of things which I mentioned in my earlier contribution that simply seek to ensure that the system encourages all parents to do the right thing and to reward them for it, and to discourage behaviour that is unhelpful or contrary to the care and development needs of the child. That is one of the great dilemmas that I have with some of the provisions and arrangements that the Child Support Agency operates under at this time: they seem to actually discourage people from doing the right thing. The person sitting in your chair on the last occasion I spoke, Madam Deputy Speaker, allowed me to use the term 'the stuff it option'. That is what far too many of my constituents say to me when they come to see me, in despair about the impact that the Child Support Agency regime is having on their lives. Too many people are saying that it is easier just to throw their job in and not put in to the community but to put in to their own care needs and, as a result, not to provide anything in the way of financial assistance for the care of the

The Child Support Agency arrangements need to be interventionist, intrusive and quite prescriptive for people who are not doing the right thing. The first is to foster greater cooperation between the Child Support Agency and the Family Court. The second is to try to work out a way of encouraging non-custodial parents to go that extra yard to do the overtime or take on that second job, to try and repair their lives at the same time as making a contribution towards the care of their child. How can we do that? There are some good ideas around and we need to work through them. I welcome the interest of the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) in this matter. Billson) with his well-chosen comments on what has been a long running issue for the parliament and, indeed, for the nation. The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 has been in the parliament for some time. It was introduced into the House on 6 March 1997 and referred to the Main Committee on 18 March 1997. The purpose of the legislation is, firstly, that custodial parents will not have to refund overpayments but, instead, future payments for the year will be reduced commensurately; secondly, that non-custodial parents will be able to make their payments directly to the CSA, rather than through an employer; and, thirdly, that the Family Court, when making property or maintenance decisions, will be able to take into account future liabilities under the Child Support Act, even if an assessment has not been made. No doubt the details have been well canvassed previously in the debate. I will not go over old ground, but I will pick up some of the points that the member for Dunkley has made. There is a great challenge for the parliament to improve the child support scheme. It is not just about the administration of the CSA, because that is symptomatic of a deeper issue, in my opinion. The child support scheme has a history of at least two decades. It goes back to the changes to the Family Law Act of Attorney-General Murphy in the Whitlam era, right through to the midto late-1980s, when the child support scheme was introduced with the Child Support Agency. Although the Child Support Agency has seen a doubling of the number of parents who are contributing to the care of their children-that is, from about 30 to 35 per cent to about 70 per cent-that still leaves 30 per cent of parents who are not fulfilling their responsibilities to care for their children. So there is much work left to be done. The Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues has been well quoted over the last 2Y2 years that it has been before the parliament. speaker: Mr Wakelin (Grey) (8.06 P.m.)
theText: It is a pleasure to follow the member for Dunkley( MrTuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4785 introduced, but there is still much work left to be done. The underlying philosophical base whereby parents have the responsibility to care for their young-in the case of the child support scheme, to the age of 18-is at the heart of this issue. The tendency not to rely sufficiently on private arrangements, as they have become known, and the tendency for the DSS to refer people readily to the CSA seem to be issues which the parliament should consider. It is pleasing to see that the member for Chifley( Mr Price) has introduced a private member's bill. I know of his deep interest in this matter and of the commitment that he, as chairman of the joint select committee, and those across the parliament made from about 1994 onwards. I am sure that the response that they received from the public and the work that went into it must have left an overwhelming impression on those members. The member for Chifley continues his long-running interest in this issue. I remember him commenting to me-and I am sure he would not mind me saying it-that too much of the focus of the child support scheme is on the corpses of dead relationships. That was a profound comment that I will never forget. The need to look forward from those failed relationships, certainly those that have children resulting from them and yet do not survive, is a key issue for the new government. That is, the new family, whatever its format, has to be considered as much as those children who remain in the previous family. The child support scheme has great difficulties, I believe, in that it falls within at least three portfolios: Social Security, Assistant Treasurer and Attorney-General. It is quite a job to try and bring those portfolios together to focus on this issue. There has been well-documented, or at least well-discussed, opposition from within the public sector and from within areas of the Department of Social Security to any change, because they believe that they have got a formula that works. Certainly it has worked somewhat better than the system in the old Family Court days. But in the opinion of many, as the member for Dunkley( Mr Billson) has mentioned, and certainly from the government side and from the back bench, there is a view that it should work a lot better. There is plenty of potential for it to show great improvement. The issues of inconsistent advice from the CSA still are constantly surfacing. There is a range of issues that I do not think I will canvass here tonight, but that the committee I have the good fortune, or otherwise, to convene is in the process of discussing. What we need to realise is that this is not a gender issue. This is an issue about fairness for families. It is an issue about the private responsibilities of parents. For it to become some kind of gender contest defeats the whole notion of the responsibility of the adult community to children. In conclusion, I do not think this is an issue that we can afford to allow to become a partisan contest. It is essential that all parents take their responsibilities to their children with the utmost care-and that, I am sure, the overwhelming majority do. The responsibility of the 30vernment is to support the principle of supporting those parents who put their children as their number one responsibility. It is not prudent for any government to have a situation where the social welfare system, the court system, or any other system undermines that fundamental responsibility of parents to their children. When you consider that we have gone from virtually zero employees employed by the Child Support Agency to about 2,400 people, at a cost to the taxpayer of something approaching $130 million for an agency that has the role of saying that parent A shall pay parent B for the care of their children, you have to ask the fundamental question of whether the pendulum has swung too far. The bipartisan acceptance of this legislation is one more small step in the 4786 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 improvement of the child support scheme. However, there is much to be done and I look forward to playing my part in that. I support the legislation. Ms GAMBARO (Petrie) (8.15 p.m.)-I rise tonight to speak on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996. Since the establishment of the child support scheme and the Child Support Agency in two stages-firstly, in June 1988 and, secondly, in October 1989-the results have been mixed with many cases bordering on frustration at a time when emotions run very high. The issue of child support is one of particular interest to me because of the large number of constituents in the Petrie electorate who have had a marriage break-up and who are directly involved in a case in the Child Support Agency or are affected through independent maintenance payments. One of the most frustrating things that I find in my dealings with constituents and the Child Support Agency is that every case is so very different. Every case deals with people who have emotions, who have different needs and different circumstances, and they need to be looked at on their individual merits. The Child Support Agency seems to have a number of loopholes which have led to great consternation and distraction in the maintenance settlements. It is important that we, as a government, take the time and effort which is necessary to sew up these loopholes. We need to listen to our constituents on these issues and we need to work through the problems for the betterment of the whole community at large. A point that needs to be made when we are dealing with the child support scheme is that each case can be terribly time consuming. As I have mentioned, the issues are complex and like any situation there are always two sides to a story. The child support scheme deals with the rights of the child. The rights of a child should always be foremost and we need to look at that very carefully. The belief is that when children are involved in their parents' divorce the children must be protected, and they must have a sustainable, great quality of life. I expect that all members of parliament in their day-to-day dealings with constituents would receive similar complaints on this issue. The main areas of concern for people tend to be on issues such as custodial parents not receiving maintenance, and repetitive or conflicting letters received by the paying parent. Many constituents have also raised with me the complexities and the concerns relating to the percentage system in deducting the level of child support to be paid. While I acknowledge that in any system that exists there will always be people who are trying to find holes or ways around it, there seems to be, in the case of child support, plenty of community discontent and a strong push for change in this area. I believe it is important to acknowledge, on behalf of all the people in Australia who are affected by this, that there are a number of huge concerns with the Child Support Agency. As a member of the government, I believe that amendments to the legislation are absolutely necessary to assist custodial and non-custodial parents and must be given absolute priority at this time. We must look at flexible legislation being introduced into this House that tries to amend some of the inequities which presently exist and look at ways to ensure that the system works well and works with people instead of against those whom it was originally intended to assist. The system must work for both parents. It must work towards providing an amicable and timely maintenance delivery as well. It must work for custodial and non-custodial parents in Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4787 such a way that the administrative procedures do not supersede posItIve results. The government is aware of some of these problems with the child support scheme and, as the previous speaker, the member for Grey( Mr Wakelin) mentioned, it is working towards that. I am happy to say that I am a member of the committee looking at reviewing this legislation and it is looking at some of the ways that we can fix some of the problems of the past. The child support legislation amendment presently before the House addresses a number of discrepancies, many of which arose from the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, which was also mentioned by the member for Grey. In the time available to me tonight I want to speak to a number of these amendments. Firstly, I wish to make a couple of points in relation to the amendment dealing with the consideration of child support liabilities in property and spousal maintenance proceedings. This amendment has important ramifications for those parents who voluntarily pay maintenance as presently the Family Court does not take this into consideration when making property and spousal arrangement judgments. There have been many who have felt that the system has failed them because property arrangements have not been taken into account when child maintenance payments were made, or that future circumstances were not taken into account. In essence, as a result of the amendments, custodial and non-custodial parents who have private arrangements will be treated exactly the same as those parents working under the guidelines as specified in the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989. This amendment ensures far more flexibility. Maintenance cases can involve property trusts and other assets, and the level of child support should be taken into account in those proceedings. The amendment also gives some forward thinking to the legislation. The legislation will now take into account private arrangements for child support and give opportunities to take into account potential liabilities under the child support scheme. A further amendment deals with employers who withhold child support from an employee's pay packet. I note that, according to the explanatory memorandum for the bill, nearly 30 per cent of those who pay child support have arranged their circumstances such that the payments are withheld by their employer. This amendment adjusts this situation and gives the option for far more flexibility for those who wish to pay child support straight to the registry. Through this amendment the payer of child support will have far more independence, and the intrusiveness which they may have felt in the past will be diminished. In some cases the employee may not wish the employer to know of their previous personal history. Administration, paperwork, and compliance costs to employers are also expected to be reduced by this move. However, I do acknowledge that there are cases where the payer may default in payments. The amendment covers these instances with a trigger mechanism which results in the employer withholcling the relevant amount of child support in those cases. Those who default will cause employers to withhold payments and they will have very limited future access to this procedure. The legislation also allows for payers to appeal if their application to pay directly is rejected by the Child Support Agency. A further advantage of this would be to reduce the cost to employers of administering the child support payment from their employees' wages. Most businesses do not object to complying with this but they do object to the terrible impost placed on them. 4788 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 A small business operator recently contacted me detailing the cost to him of collecting child support on behalf of the Australian Taxation Office. It was absolutely horrendous. The administrative costs included cheques, bank charges, stationery, postage and computer processing. For this particular company, when all those costs were taken into account, it amounted to $12.36 per week per employee, which totals $642.72 per year. Just imagine the enormous savings that can be made to private enterprise, and to the government as an employer, if those who pay child support can opt to make their own arrangements. There are a number of other amendments in the bilI also in reference to the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 which bring them into line with references to the Social Security Act 1991. These are necessary for continuity and consistency. On the whole, the legislation acts as the first step in the federal government's process of reviewing the whole child support scheme. I am sure that both sides of the House can support this process to streamline the child support legislation. I believe it is really important that we have support on both sides for this legislation and that we work towards ensuring the benefits for both parties involved. The Child Support Act does have problems and there are some great concerns out there, but this government is making a major commitment to fix those problems. because what I have to say and the sentiments that I have about the child support scheme have been expressed by those who have already spoken in the debate on the Child Support Legislation Amendment BilI (No. 1) 1996. The fact that over 80,000 Australians have signed petitions pertaining to child support and the Family Law Act is indicative of the animosity in the community in relation to both these laws. Of all the issues brought to my attention by my constituents, there is none more voluminous, and none which causes more emotion and grief, than that dealing with child support and family law. I am certainly not envious of the minister responsible for the Child Support Act, the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp). To have responsibility for that and for superannuation is a double-whammy poisoned chalice, if I can put it that way. The bilI being debated makes changes to certain aspects of the child support scheme. The objective of child support is certainly justified, as we have all noted. The child support scheme came into effect in 1988 with the objective of requiring both custodial and non-custodial parents to pay for the maintenance of their children rather than leave it to the taxpayers-who are, too often, expected to provide for all the needs of so many people in our community. While the objective is certainly worthy, to put that objective into legislation is a difficult task by any means, as we have discovered over the years. There is no way that, on issues such as child support and family law, any parliament would be able to provide legislation which is suitable to all people. Nevertheless, as a member of parliament, you do hear of cases which make you wonder how our laws allow to take place certain practices that, at the end of the day, ultimately affect not the parents but the child, who is always the innocent victim in such disputes-although that point is quickly forgotten. The first change provided by the bill allows a non-custodial parent to seek a revision of their payments owing, if they believe their income is less than 15 per cent of the previous year's income. This wilI, of course, amend the non-custodial parent's child support assessment. If a custodial parent has received an overpayment, this bilI will allow them to receive reduced

speaker: Mr Eoin Cameron (Stirling) (8.25 P.m.)
theText: I do not intend taking up too much time,Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4789 payments accordingly until the ledger is balanced, so to speak, rather than having to pay back the overpayment. One child support case that I had brought to my attention dealt with the matter of a noncustodial parent overpaying the custodial parent. Apparently the Child Support Agency wrote to the gentleman offering three options: reducing payments until the overpayment was offset; taking a payment from the CSA of the equivalent of the overpayment; or giving the payment to the custodial parent as a gift. I thought that final option was a misnomer, given that the parents obviously had irreconcilable differences which had brought them to the situation that they were in. As such, it was not surprising that the non-custodial parent did not take up the final option. While this amendment is welcomed, it will still leave many clients of the Child Support Agency quite dissatisfied. The theme of many complaints to my office is in relation to the assessments made by the CSA, and the fact that the information used for the decisions affecting their assessments does not reflect the actual situation that the non-custodial parent is in. People ask me why, when they are earning X amount of dollars, the CSA assesses them as though they are earning Z amount of dollars. I hope that this amendment will provide the relief that those people require who are earning less than they are assessed as earning, notwithstanding their obligations to their child or children. That is the paramount point. I only say that because I know that I will still have people coming to my office complaining about their assessments and the facts and figures used to calculate them. The second change effected by the bill is to allow non-custodial parents to make their payments direct to the Child Support Agency rather than have them deducted from their pay and forwarded to the CSA by their employer. This move is consistent with other legislation that has come before the House, such as the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill which allowed the parent's child-care payments to be paid directly to the child-care provider. This reduces the intrusiveness into what is essentially a private matter between family members. If the non-custodial parent chooses, there is no need to require the employer to deduct pay from a non-custodial parent for forwarding to the CSA. The previous situation implied that the non-custodial parent could not be trusted to make payments to the CSA and that the payments should be compulsorily deducted from their pay beforehand. This is a logical amendment that I am sure non-custodial parents will find completely welcome. They know that they have a responsibility for the upkeep of their children, and the vast majority will not shirk their responsibility and will continue making their payments personally, without the intrusion of a third party. My principal concern is that the CSA pass the payments on punctually, which is but another topic of complaint that I receive about this particular subject. The final change deals with potential child support liabilities when the Family Court is making decisions on property or maintenance. In closing, I would like to read to you a letter which I received on 29 May, which is so typical of letters that I receive concerning this particular subject. Obviously, I will leave my constituent's name private. The letter reads: I am writing to ask you to raise the issue of child maintenance in parliament, specifically to amend the laws of the Child Support Agency. BeforeI begin let me state that I want to support my family and I know it is right that I should do so. My situation and many others I have spoken to about this subject is: I earn around about $30,000 a year working from about 80 to 100 hours a fortnight; I am living in a rented duplex, I drive a 30 year old car 4790 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 and I'm BROKE. ThoughI live a mangy, pitiful existence I am expending a little more every fortnight than my net income; and you know what the means. After accounting my expenditure which includes just normal everyday bills with the exception of tithing I pay to my church-which is tax deductible-I am left with about $3000 for the year for buying clothes, entertainment, birthday/Christmas presents for the kids and the mother/wife, little luxuries like haircuts and medication which cost me about $300 to $400 a year and a variety of miscellaneous things. I have a personal loan for a computer which is $70 a fortnight, the rest as I have said is just living costs. I dream of one day buying a house and starting my life again. I would like to buy another car to replace the one that is breaking up around me. IfI found another companion I would like to be able to keep her. I would like to think that I am getting ahead and moving forward and maybe having the benefit of joying in some little reward that I can give myself for supporting my family and paying my taxes and doing the right thing. But in sad reality, I can not. And the cruel hard fact of the matter is, I never can. IfI work overtime or work myself to near death with one or two other jobs to get ahead then bang, I am hit with a greater child support bill the year after. Most importantly is my relationship with my children. I have lost the benefit of watching my children grow up and having them around me as a family. Now it's twice a fortnight I have my kids sleep over. I would like to be in a position to compensate for my separation from the children, on the days that I see them by taking them out and spending a little money on them and supporting them directly instead of indirectly. When my rostered days off come around and I have my kids over I have very little money to do anything but feed them. This situation leaves people to either give up to the extent they want to give up; Go on the dole; Earn undeclared cash money or tum to criminal activities to get ahead. ThisI cannot do and why should I have to resort to immoral or illegal activities to live? IfI cannot afford to pay petrol or maintenance costs for my vehicle then I have no alternative but to cease work. Or if the physiological impact of being separated from the family, working in a stressful job and then having nothing to show for it but the worry of mounting bills, poverty and bankruptcy; if this anxiety and sorrow causes a break down then, what is the advantage in this? I would cease paying tax; The government would be obliged to pay my sickness/unemployment benefits and completely supporting my wife and kids. Isn't it better that I am working and paying tax and willing to help support my children? Now in the name of equality I would like to mention my wife and her charmed life. She is buying a house in a suburb of Perthshe drives around in a late model van, it appears that she can buy clothes for herself and go out whenever she wills, and she has the added benefit of having the children with her and buying things for them and taking them out etc, which I think is great; I am happy for her and I am grateful the kids have a good home to live in and a loving mother to look after them. My humble prayer is not to have what she has but at least have half the benefits and joys and opportunities that she has. At the moment I have zilch, zero, naught, nothing. The simple fact of the matter is, it isn't fair. So for this reason I would like the child support laws changed ... He goes on to say: ... I'll leave it with you in the hope that you maybe able to do something to address the gross inequalities, burden and distress child support indirectly fosters amongst the many Australians whose only crime is, is that they for one reason or another, could not live with their companions. Faithfully yours. I think that letter just about says it all. WhilstI have no hesitation in supporting this bill, I do not think it will stop the tide of complaints that we all have coming into our offices concerning child support. As I said at the beginning of my speech, over 80,000 people have signed petitions airing grievances about child support and family laws. That displays the Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4791 inadequacies of the legislation, although I do not intend for that to imply blame. I simply do not believe one will ever be able to write legislation that pleases everyone in these disputes. Given the dissatisfaction with these laws, minor amendments will not, in my view, stop the tide of complaints. Indeed, it has almost become a tidal wave of complaints and I have no doubt that the day will come when completely new legislation will need to be drafted replacing both the Child Support Act and the Family Law Act. I do not see why that should be later rather than sooner. I think the new laws should be on the agenda of all political parties. for this debate on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill. This is a very tough area; there are no easy answers here. There is an interaction between family law issues with issues involving access to children, property law and so on. There are people who deny this but these issues are certainly not separate in the minds of those who are affected. I want to take this opportunity to put forward an idea which I have had in mind for some time in relation to property settlements. I would be interested in parliamentary and public reaction. Family law is presently extremely costly, both to public legal aid and private legal parties. Many of the outcomes are not well regarded by the parties who are involved with them and a lot of them have a poisonous effect on interpersonal relationships. I think we need to look at codifying property settlements so that people know exactly where they stand so that there is no need to litigate. I am interested in a system analogous to what happens with wills where the government regards as legally enforceable any agreement concerning property division in the event of separation or divorce made either before marriage or during marriage. However, in the absence of any such agreement we would have all property split fifty-fifty in the event of a marriage breakdown, without regard to the issue of contribution or who has custody of the children and so on. I am also interested in the idea of an opt-out provision concerning child support whereby both parents would be given the option of assuming up to 50 per cent of the responsibility for maintenance of their children. If they agree to accept 50 per cent responsibility, the Child Support Agency would not be involved in that particular family circumstance. Of course, if they did not want to do that then the child support arrangements would apply. There has been a lot of debate about legal aid cuts in the context of the Commonwealth budget. It has a massive family law budget-I think, in excess of $100 million-and it does seem to me that we ought to be able to do a lot better than we are doing. The second thing I want to do is pay tribute to the work done by the member for Chifley, ( Mr Price), in this area. Child support is a work in progress and it is remarkable to see the extent of the praise coming to the member for Chifley from both sides of the chamber. So much so that I think it is worth drawing attention to some of the specific references. The member for Sturt( Mr Pyne) pointed out that the member for Chifley headed up the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, and also pointed out that this committee broke the record for the number of submissions received by a joint select committee or a standing committee on any issue being investigated. He said that the member for Chifley did a very good job with his committee. That has been said by other speakers in this debate, and I am sure it will be said throughout the debate. Indeed, the member for Kalgoorlie ( Mr Campbell) said:
