speaker: Mr Kelvin Thomson (Wills) (8.36 P.m.)
theText: It is nice to have an audience of such size4792 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 I think that the Price report did a good job. I believe that we should be looking more closely at that report and doing more in this regard. The member for Bowman( Mrs West) said: My congratulations go to the member for Chifley( Mr Price) on the Price report. He did an excellent job. It is now up to the government to put these recommendations into place. Then later we find the member for Dawson( Mrs De-Anne Kelly) saying: I would simply like to conclude by saying that many excellent recommendations have been made in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Matters, and I believe that they do need to be addressed. We also had the member for Canning( Mrs Johnston) saying: BeforeI start, I would like to commend the work that has been done by the member for Chifley( Mr Price). Not only is he very passionate about what he is doing, but he has also put a lot of work into it in previous years, and I congratulate him for it. None of those members are Labor members. There are Labor members who supported the work of the member for Chifley, such as the member for Isaacs( Mr Wilton). But I think it reflects a remarkable degree of support for his conscientiousness and basic sense of fairness and decency on these issues, and I personally start with a presumption that his views in this area ought to be accorded a great deal of weight. The third thing that I wish to do is to support the amendments moved by the member for Werriwa( Mr Latham) concerning the bill before the parliament. I think these amendments are worth repeating. The member for Werriwa has moved that the House: (1) expresses concern at the failure of the Howard Government, after 12 months in office, to respond to the recommendations of the report of the Joint Select Committee into Certain Family Law Issues, entitled 'Child Support Scheme: An Examination of the Operation and Effectiveness of the Scheme'; (2) believes the Government should be concerned about the well-being and welfare of all families: whether they be intact families, separated families, single parent families or serial families; (3) notes with concern the failure to implement some of the report's recommendations has caused parents and their children to suffer needless hardship; (4) believes that there is important and urgent need to improve and strengthen the Child Support Scheme; and (5) considers that much time has been lost and therefore the Government should respond to the recommendations of the report concerned with changing the child support formula as soon as possible and introduce legislation within six months to this effect. This is an issue about which massive community concern has been expressed. That has been noted by previous speakers from all sides. I will just note a couple of the observations of the member for Calare( Mr Andren) who said: By far the most angry and disgruntled group of people are the men who have lost custody of their children and have also lost out or come out with a lesser share in the divorce settlement. They are now paying substantial amounts of income in child support. In many cases their former wives have now found new partners and so have an extra income coming in. The way men see it, they have lost their wife, their house and their kids, and are now continuing to lose a large slice of their income. Similarly, the member for Capricornia ( Mr Marek) reported to the parliament on a national conference on family law issues held by the Lone Fathers Association. He noted a set of groups which attended this conference, including DADS, the Child Support Action Group, Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4793 Reform, Parents Without Partners, and others as well. It is an extraordinary flowering of groups, if you like. We are not a nation of joiners. To have so many groups which have arisen to try and address some of the issues in this area does suggest that it is an area of substantial concern. I have had the same sort of feedback in my own electorate. The previous speaker, the member for Stirling( Mr Eoin Cameron) referred to cases and correspondence which he had received. I have received a number of similar letters, including one from a woman whose husband was previously married. She and her husband have one child. She went through the child support formula and said that, from her point of view, the two children of her husband's first marriage were being regarded as more valuable than children that she has with this man. She regards that as a most unfair situation. When she challenged this, she said, 'We were told by the Child Support Agency that disregarded income levels for custodial parents are as high as they are to encourage them to work.' Her observation is that since the child support becomes so large, why in fact would they work? In this particular case, the husband had been staying home to look after the child-and, in this day and age, a lot of people would regard it as very appropriate and quite reasonable for husbands to stay at home and look after their children. As a result, he was not earning any income. His former wife challenged the idea that he was not earning any income under ground 8 of the grounds of application. It says: The income, earning capacity, property and financial resources of one of the parents or the child are not properly reflected in the assessment. I have to say that, when I look at that ground, it seems to me to be extraordinarily open-ended and to give the child support review officers an extraordinary amount of discretion. In fu:t, in this case, the assessment was made that the husband was able to provide child support, notwithstanding that he did not have an income. In the report of this case, the review officer said: I note that the Payer's new wife is therefore able to work full time to support the family. What is clearly going on here is that the husband's income is not being taken into account but his wife's income is being taken into account. This seems to me to be an unusual state of affairs and one which certainly can give rise to anomalies. We do receive correspondence of this kind. There was another letter from a person in New South Wales who, I assume, wrote to all members of parliament. In his case, he said that the amount being deducted by the Child Support Agency was close to five times in excess of the amount that he had agreed on with his ex-wife. Initially, she agreed to refund the excess amount that came to her but, after the payments started, she was not interested in doing so. In his letter he says: I do not understand how the government can say that the more money I earn, the more my children cost to raise. This is reflective of the substantial community concern that has arisen in this area.1ille Nrn; are reflected in the statements made by the member for Werriwa( Mr Latham) when he put forward the opposition's amendment. In so doing, he expressed concern that the government, after 12 months in office, had failed to respond to the basic findings and recommendations of the parliamentary report of 1994 and that delay was occurring in addressing these issues. He pointed out that this committee had received something like 6,200 submissions, the largest number of submissions ever received by any committee of this parliament. The member for 4794 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 Werriwa also made some important comments about some of the fundamental concepts at stake here. He said: As is so often the case with these win-lose scenarios, the child support area has been seen through the prism of gender equity issues. He also said: It is also much healthier for the parliament and parliamentarians to consider child support through the prism of income equity concerns and to examine the fairness of the existing income transfers implicit in the formula. He went on to say: We should blindfold ourselves to whether the parent is male or female, and rather take an income equity focus on these questions. He further said: ... by blindfolding ourselves to the gender equity concerns, the parliament can have a far healthier and productive debate. That is an accurate way to look at these issues and to try to deal with them conceptually. I have a couple of additional remarks that I would like to make before concluding. One is that the member for Dawson( Mrs De-Anne Kelly) referred to the idea of linking child support and access issues. I have to say that the law to date, or certainly in recent times, has regarded these as entirely distinct issues and has not been willing to see it that way. I do think, having spoken to quite a few parents who have been on the sharp end of the child support and access issues, that there is something in what the member for Dawson is saying, because you do get a situation where, if access orders are being flouted, the non-custodial parent is required to go to court himself or herself to seek court orders. There is always the onus of time, energy and expense resting on them, whereas, if a child support order is flouted, you have the full majesty of the Taxation Office and the Child Support Agency coming down on the person in breach of the child support order. It does seem to me that consideration ought to be given to some linkage or to at least developing a situation where those issues are dealt with in a more comparable way. Finally, I think that family law and child support issues are a work in progress. My ideas on this issue are developing, as I believe that all of our ideas need to develop, in the light of experience. But the case for some action now is indeed overwhelming and government legislation, which picks up only some of the Price committee recommendations, simply does not go far enough. I do not think it is good enough for coalition members, pre-election, to be picking up votes by bagging the Child Support Agency and child support arrangements. It is now up to coalition members to actually do something about it. Supporting or taking on board the amendments proposed by the member for Werriwa would be a very good place to start. Miss JACKIE KELLY (Lindsay) (8.51 p.m.)-I rise tonight to represent the numerous paying parents in the seat of Lindsay who have come to see me over the last 14 months regarding the efficacy of the child support legislation. It is interesting to note, in any discussion on this subject, the actual history of child support and the Family Law Act. When the Family Law Act was first introduced in 1975, it was only a small act of about one centimetre in thickness. It was designed to simplify the whole family law relationship and to move away from the concept of fault in any relationship breakdown. That act is now a three-volume practice manual of about 10 inches in thickness. The Child Support Agency Act was introduced in 1988. Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4795 By now, we are well away from the concept of fault. We are well down the track where there is an accepted community morality about the obligations to pay child support. Yet there are parties leaving a marital break-up who feel like criminals. The intrusion into their personal affairs has been to such an extent that they have felt hounded. They have often given up jobs, given up employment prospects and moved into a cash society to avoid moral obligations or social obligations. This act goes some way to mending their feelings in terms of being able to hide from employers the fact that they have had a marital bust-up or that they are in fact experiencing some personal problems. I think that is an important olive branch to offer in the family law disputes that do take place in today's society. It is something that this society is going to have to deal with and deal with in a very humane fashion, because more and more marriages are breaking up and more and more families are now second or third families. It is those people in those relationships that need to be considered. Gone are the days where people will break up after a 20or 30-year marriage when no more children will be forthcoming. These days, you will find that, quite frequently, there are three or four children-all under the age of IS-from different parents, and all liable to be attracting child support. When you have 27 per cent of your gross wage going towards paying for two children from a previous marriage, you are probably paying 47 per cent in tax, and you are left with 26 per cent of your wage for your second family, which may have up to three children and a dependent spouse, you start to get very concerned about the efficaciousness of this legislation. It has resulted in an inordinate number of complaints. By reducing the intrusiveness on people's subsequent lives when they move on from a marital break-up, when they move into further relationships, when they move into further employment prospects, they feel that it gives them a chance to mend old wounds. It gives them a chance to move on and develop a better working relationship with their previous spouse. That is crucial for the forward progress of this society. We need to achieve the original objectives of the Family Law Act 1975. We need to get to the stage where these matters are resolved by the couple on a basis that each feels has dealt with their needs. They need to feel that they have been fairly dealt with. They need to have a basis for continuing with their current and future living arrangements, and for continually changing. The adversarial system-the number of complaints and the number of political organisations that have formed such as the Lone Parents Association, DADS and the Family Law Reform Party-is an indication that there is growing distress from marital break-up. The purpose of this legislation at all times-and into the future-is to move these matters out of the legal system and into a social and community context, into alternative dispute resolution and into support for future families from both parents. It is not a male or female issue. Quite frequently these days, the female is the paying parent and, quite frequently, it is the female of a second or third marriage who is wearing the consequences of prior relationships. These things, in light of a changing society and very mobile family relationships, are going to continue to be part of society. Our definition of family continually needs to evolve and we continually need to update legislation to make it reflect the times. Most paying parents have a very sincere attitude to their children. They want to have a continuing relationship with the children and they spend an enormous amount of money on 4796 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 their children when they have access. Child support needs to take into account a number of payments that paying parents are already making. This act goes some way to delivering, for the paying parent, a feeling that their concerns are being listened to by government, that there is some hope in the future before their children tum 18 when they can mend the fences with their previous spouse and get to some cordial social relationship where they can, between themselves, make payments to each other. It also gives the parents a chance to choose how they are going to pay for their child support. By voluntarily paying it to the parent with custodial obligations, it takes the fault away from the paying spouse. They then feel that their personal affairs are not aired in public with their employers by having their wages garnisheed or by having to do battle in that adversarial manner with the Child Support Agency. They feel more adult about getting on with their responsibilities to their children and their previous relationships, whilst still leaving room for them to get on with new relationships and family matters. This bill is a very important step. It certainly does not go far enough, and the committee is working to move in the direction of answering all concerns in this area, both for the custodial spouse and for the paying parent. With that, I commend the bill to the House. spend the first couple of minutes relating a story that came to me today. It is not particularly related to the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1), but it is certainly related to the issue of what this bill addresses. To those present tonight who are mums and dads-and I stress that what I am going to say to you, as the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) said, is not a male or female issue; it can happen to either parent-you might understand what I am going to say to you. One of my staff, in fact, has separated from his spouse and there has been a terrible problem in that separation. My staff member lives on Magnetic Island so has to catch a ferry from the mainland to the island. The other spouse, in fact, spends quite a lot of time on Magnetic Island and catches a similar ferry. There is a child of that relationship and just on the weekend that particular spouse and child were on the ferry when the person who works for me also got on that ferry. When the person got on the ferry the young child who is a young man of about four years of age saw his father and said, 'Daddy. Daddy,' and basically called to him to come. So the father in that situation went to his son, took him in his arms and hugged him, and spent some time with his son. When the ferry got to the other end of the journey to Magnetic Island, the other spouse went straight to the police and reported the father for stalking and for attempting to abduct his son. What a sad situation this would be. How you would abduct your son on a ferry I do not know. Those of us who have a loving relationship and who have sons and daughters can understand how a dad would feel in that situation. I do not know why this is happening. In my own marriage I have a wonderful relationship. I have a wonderful son and daughter. But how can we in our society today have a situation where dads or mums cannot see their sons or daughters when they should see them. What is wrong with us? What is wrong with our society? At the moment I feel the way the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Beazley) did. I did not intend this, but it is just how I feel. Why do parents have to separate? Why do they have to use each other in this way. No-one cares about the kids. Thank God, Margaret, Mark and I and my daughter, Kylie, are a loving family.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Lindsay (Herbert) (8.59 P.m.)
theText: Madam Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, I willTuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4797 I should get back to the text of my speech now. When I became a member of parliament I was astonished by the level of public concern regarding family law and child support issues. Often the two are confused which does not help matters. It did not take me long to get an indication of the depth of the problems that I was being confronted with from day one in my term as a member of the federal parliament. Even now, some 14 months down the track, it is still difficult to know where to begin addressing the problems my constituents bring to me. I see on a daily basis examples of how the current CSA system is not working. My Townsville office staff have lost count of the number of times that they have taken calls from women and men who have gone through the Family Court and the child support system and have come out the other end almost literally with nothing to live for. It is heart breaking to listen to grown men and women fall to pieces over the phone because they have not seen their children for months on end even though they are legally entitled to see them, or because they have not received any child support payments. I can understand why people talk openly about living only from one day to the next and seriously contemplating on a daily basis taking their lives. As much as I admire the people who work in the Townsville Child Support Agency, they can only operate under the system we helped set up for them and we know that, while the system has vastly improved over recent years, it is still not working. I will support the changes presented in this bill, but I think everyone who has spoken on this bill recognises the need to go much further in terms of legislative changes. Half-hearted attempts to change the system will not really achieve the change for the better we all know the system desperately needs. We all know family breakdown can tum into a very bitter and nasty affair. One party blames the other; they both get lawyers; both parties seem willing to do or say anything to get custody of children, and so it goes. We might have to be mindful that, when we do try to change the way in which the CSA operates, we may change it for the benefit of one party, but to the detriment of the other, be they custodial or non-custodial. We also need to be mindful of the fact that, in dealing with cases of family breakdown, you simply are not going to be able to please 100 per cent of the people 100 per cent of the time. We need to weigh up the pros and cons of legislative change and act to make the CSA as workable and as fair as possible. My fear is that, if we set out to please everybody, we will end up with half-hearted reforms that will not go to the root of the problems members and senators see walking through their doors-week in, week out. By far and away, the largest number of Townsville CSA related complaints I receive come from the non-custodial parents. I receive, as I am sure every other member of this House does, many complaints from custodial parents about the Child Support Agency. More often than not those complaints are from women who are faced with having to make repayments because the child support paying father's income has changed. This often places custodial parents in a very difficult financial position. However, in between his income changing and the administrative process recognising the change in income status occurring, the paying parent is still paying at a higher rate than he can afford. The receiving parent is at the same time being overpaid and running up a bill she will have to repay once the system catches up with the change in the paying parent's income. This impacts on both parents, the custodial and the non-custodial. I have seen, on more than one occasion, mothers come into my Townsville office in tears because they have just received a letter telling them that they have to pay back a considerable sum of money because of overpayments. In cases I have personally come across, quite often the single mother is not in 4798 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 a position where she can repay this money, certainly not in one lump sum and certainly not in the time indicated on the letter that she receives. The proposed amendment will reduce the incidence of overpayments to persons receiving child support which currently arise because of the retrospective effect of an income estimate election. It will better reflect a payer's future capacity to pay because the amount payable will only be changed for the months remaining after the estimate has been lodged. It will reduce the level of child support arrears that may arise when payers spend amounts refunded to them as overpayments, but later do not have the funds to meet their advised ongoing child support liability. I certainly hope that this will be the case. The explanatory memorandum further states, in relation to the use of election where income changed, the parents paying child support will still pay the correct amount for the year based on the income estimate. If overpayments are made, they will reduce the remaining child support liability for the remaining part of the year. Similarly, underpayments will be offset evenly throughout the remainder of the year and this is a very good position to be in. These are good measures, which will take some pressure off the child support receiving parents, who instead of being faced with repaying overpayments, will instead have their repayments reduced for a period of time to reflect the relative size of the overpayment. I think that such a change will be easier for child support recipients to manage. I have in the parliament today a petition of 1,300 signatures calling on reforms for the Child Support Agency and family law system. This petition was compiled by Mr Laurie Chalker in my electorate. Mr Chalker was due to start a marathon run from Townsville to Canberra last month in protest at the way in which the CSA and the family law systems do not work. Unfortunately, his run had to be cancelled. Had he been able to travel all the way to Canberra collecting signatures, this group of signatures would have been but a small fraction of what Laurie would have been able to collect. That brings me to another point. All the people with CSA problems who walk through our individual electorate doors are but pieces of a very large jigsaw. The fact that so many members have spoken on this bill, and intend to speak on this bill, is evidence that Child Support Agency problems are not confined to just Queensland, Tasmania or Victoria. As elected representatives speaking on this bill we are individual pieces in a much larger jigsaw. I am the Herbert piece; Bruce Billson Individually, we may just be one voice representing one small part of Australia. But, if you take us collectively, all the small pieces add up to form a very large picture. That picture is of the mums and dads, and most importantly of all the children, caught up in family breakdown as they are crying out for change and reform. It was only last week I was visited by a constituent, in this case a custodial parent, and it was a lady. She said, ' Mr Lindsay, I've just received a bill for $2,000 that I must pay because the Child Support Agency has overpaid me. I've spent that money in the last six months, I've spent it on my children. I run a very tight financial position but I now have this bill that I must pay. How do I pay it?' That is what we are dealing with tonight. These are the sorts of things that the government and the opposition, in a bipartisan way, need to be mindful of and need to do something about. I have certainly been very active in working on the government members' Child Support Agency subcommittee because I believe that we have a responsibility as members of this parliament to try to correct the wrongs that exist currently in the system. I can understand the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Is The Dunkley Piece; Mr Mcclelland Is The Barton Piece, And So On.
theText: Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4799 impatience to have these wrongs corrected. Since the recommencement of the parliamentary sittings I have been telling my constituents that we must make changes to the legislation, and what we are dealing with tonight is part of that. It is now June; we are still going. The worse part about it is that no-one is really disagreeing with what we are trying to do, whether it be on the opposition side or on the government side. I hope that together we can do something that will be for the benefit of those families who have been split in unfortunate circumstances. While tonight's legislative changes are relatively small, I find it a bit disconcerting that we simply cannot push it through because while we talk and adjourn, and talk and adjourn, people's lives are being adversely affected. I certainly hope that we can get support tonight for this bill. I invite all of my colleagues to support it, as I do. Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996. I think we all know the philosophy behind the Child Support Agency. That philosophy is that if you bring a child into the world then you take responsibility for that child, whether your relationship with your partner continues or not. Too often in the past husbands, and de facto husbands, deserted their wives and left their children to the tender mercies of the state. It is not fair that the taxpayers of Australia should pay for the irresponsibility of those fathers, or for that matter those mothers, who for one reason or another desert their children, yet may well have the means to support them, totally or in part. So the Child Support Agency was brought in to correct this anomaly. It depended on an order from the court or a percentage payment levied on the non-custodial parent to support his or her children. It was collected by an agency within the taxation department. All those things are quite appropriate mechanisms but I do not think the original system took sufficient note of the human dimension of this problem. Such a system depends on goodwill and where that is absent there can be a lack of equality or empowerment. WhatI mean by that is that both parties initially, at the time when arrangements are made or need to be modified, should be able to represent their case in an equal and unfettered way. But quite often we see the situation where one party has legal aid and the other party has not. That of itself I think leads to quite an imbalance in the outcome. I suppose that-as most do when they come into this job as a member of parliament-I felt that the responsibility to the CSA and the matter of custody and access were separate and distinct issues. After four years in the job I do not believe that any longer. In fact, I believe the diametrical opposite. Regardless of what previous parliaments have said, regardless of what my own party or the Labor Party have said, I have come inexorably to the conclusion that those two things are linked. I believe that the custodial parent-the one in receipt of child support-has both a financial and custodial advantage. If this is not exercised with equanimity and natural justice a gross distortion and disadvantage occurs to the non-custodial parent. For example, where a custodial parent says, 'Yes, under the terms of the arrangement made by the court you can have the children for the school holidays but you will have to pay the airfares,' which might be quite considerable, what that often does is deprive the non-custodial parent of the short.number of weeks-two, four or six weeks a year-that that parent might have the children; it deprives the parent of the ability to give them a decent and meaningful holiday; and it deprives them of the opportunity to create a relationship with the children, albeit over a very short period.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Neville (Hinkler) (9.13 P.m.)
theText: I wish to speak this evening on the Child Support4800 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 Perhaps if the custodial parent is totally manipulative they might put it on the non-custodial parent, even over that short period, to provide the children with new clothes, school clothes for the coming year or warm clothes if there is a climatic change. In other words, the kids become a sort of bargaining chip. They become collateral in the relationship. I am deeply saddened when I see non-custodial parents, generally the fathers-and I do not say that with any sexist overtones whatsoever; it is generally the fathers-deprived of a meaningful relationship with their children. I believe this could be addressed very easily, as indeed the recognition of the interrelationship between custody and access on one hand and maintenance on the other would confirm. I feel that on those occasions where the non-custodial parent is in control of the children, whether the maintenance payments be voluntary or court established, the maintenance payment should be suspended for the non-custodial parent. In other words, if the non-custodial parent is taking care of the children during that period, then the equivalent of the fees should go to them. It could be argued that the custodial parent has responsibilities over and above that in the home--electricity, rates, rent and so on-that continue whether the children are there or not and that perhaps there could be some formularisation of this on a one-third/two-thirds basis. In principle, I think that should be the case. During times of voluntarily agreed or court established access, the non-custodial parent should not have to pay any form of maintenance, or perhaps only a limited amount to cover the ongoing running costs of the home. This would be a discipline on manipulative custodial parents. A person might be using the kids as a weapon against the non-custodial parent. She might be making it as hard as possible for him to have the kids, saying things like, 'I'm going to make sure that he pays the fares and buys the kids warm clothes-I'm going to make it as difficult as possible for him.' Or she might say, 'I'm going to say that the kids have got the flu and they can't come for four weeks; they can only come for two.' In that situation, whatever the court or the voluntary agreement determined in terms of access would be invoked. For the period that was laid down in that agreement or that court access, the payments by the non-custodial parent to the custodial parent would be suspended. I think that would solve a lot of problems very simply and very effectively. If we are sincere about this, if we are fair dinkum that the welfare of the children should be the dominant feature of these relationships, then they cannot be used as collateral; they cannot be used as bargaining chips. I have heard of some horrific cases where fathers have waited for years to see their kids and, because of personal animosity between the mother and the father, the mother decides that she is going to put every possible barrier in the way of the father. That sometimes spills over into even more vindictive activities. It is sad, too, that some sections of the legal fraternity are not lilywhite in this matter. There is a system in vogue at present, if the lawyers I speak to are any measure of the activity, that says that when a person is in a disadvantageous situation in a custody hearing, regardless of whether her ex-spouse is violent or not, regardless of whether he has been showing animus towards the wife or not, a restraining order is taken out against him-not because he has done anything wrong, but because that will place the custodial parent in an advantageous position in the court hearing. What is even worse-and this appals me right to my very core-is that quite often the charge is made that the father has sexually molested the children. Over the last four years, an Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4801 increasing number of non-custodial parents-in nearly all cases fathers-have come to me as white as a sheet saying, 'I have never had any criminal conviction of any sort against me in my life. NowI am accused of molesting my children. I can no longer see them, except under supervision'--or in some cases not at all-'because of the charge made by my former spouse.' It is a shocking and deliberate evil that is perpetrated that destroys the relationship between the non-custodial parent and the children. The children, of course, know it is false, but society does not, and it places all the people in the chain-the Family Court, the bailiffs, the police and all those that get involved in these activities-in a horrendous position. I have seen this in the case of a constituent in my electorate-and I repeat this in many of these speeches because I cannot get it out of my mind. When the actual court cases for custody and separation were going on, his wife received legal aid, whereas he hitchhiked on semitrailers some 1,000 kilometres or more from my electorate to Sydney. He went into court unrepresented. His former wife went into court with, on one occasion, a solicitor and two barristers. Despite this, he made a very good fist of it. The wife perjured herself on numerous occasions and got custody of the children, claiming to take them to a new relationship with her parents in western New South Wales. Within a month she was in a de facto relationship in North Queensland. I saw that father with his limited resources do everything he could to regain those children. He had lost his home, a very successful business, and access to his children. But his wife used her position quite unconscionably and finally he was able to bring her to court in North Queensland for defiance of the custody arrangements in contempt of the Family Court. In the course of that particular case she argued-by the way, without any disclosure of this prior to the case-that some 11 years earlier he had molested her sister. On the basis of that charge, on what was probably the penultimate case in that custody hearing, that father from that day to this did not see his kids except under supervision. I just find it appalling. But what is even worse is that, on the basis of this charge, the New South Wales police have charged him with interfering with that girl 11 years earlier. It is not for me to go into that case because it is before the courts but I just want to show you one of the extreme cases of the disintegration of a family. At the end of the day, what was the separation all about? Was it not for a better life for each of them and for the kids? What have they all ended up with: total and utter misery and the kids not knowing whether they are coming or going. I think in the time that is available to me I would like to say something about second families. Many speakers have spoken of them. The Child Support Agency recognises that when there is a break-up the children of the custodial parent often enter a new relationship. Sometimes it is one of great opulence and wealth and quite often the non-custodial parent, already deprived of his children, finds a new relationship. Sometimes that relationship involves the children of his new partner-his stepchildren. But they are receiving no child support from their father or their non-custodial parent because, perhaps, he was a waster, or a pensioner. Perhaps he was not in a position to pay any maintenance payments and for that reason the children of that second family, and the whole family, live at a gross disadvantage. I believe that what we have to do is not have these ironclad rules but, rather, look at the whole family situation. Does anyone seriously pretend that when the custodial parent goes into an opulent relationship and gets maintenance payments from the previous, non-custodial parent, the payments are going to be divvied up between the children and the stepchildren strictly in 4802 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 accordance with the way the father pays maintenance? Of course not. All the kids are going to be treated equally-and so they should be. But when you come back to the other family, the second family of the non-custodial parent, quite often there is no wealth, and there is no adjusting mechanism made available. I also believe that we need a more effective way of being able to alter arrangements. I had a case where a wife went off the rails mentally, claimed that she had separated from her husband, received maintenance payments for some years, and had them sent to a false address. It was a very clever scam, actually. It was not until her husband noticed how his tax refund cheques were falling and queried, on the third year, how he could lose the $4,000 refund he was expecting that he discovered it. They said, 'You are separated from your wife.' He said, 'NoI am not.' He subsequently did separate from her. But during that period it was established by statutory declarations, by declarations from neighbours, that during the period for which this huge Child Support Agency bill had accumulated they had indeed not been separated. In fact, he had not been out of the family home for more than three nights in the whole period. When I put that whole case to the Child Support Agency-and admittedly it was before the previous inquiry that we had in the last parliament, so I imagine things have improved, but it illustrates the point-there was no automatic adjustment. He was told, 'There is nothing we can do about that. You will have to take it back to the court.' Where there is clear evidence like that, why put the whole system to that financial burden? In an instance like that, I think there should be something in provincial cities. Perhaps if we had Child Support Agency magistrates who would sit in the magistrate's court in the main provincial cities, they could hear these matters quickly and issue an order varying the regulations or the arrangements, rather than taking the whole business back through the Family Court. Surely something like that would be preferable. I have only touched on a few points tonight, but I think they are very important points. As I said before, if we are fair dinkum about the welfare of the children, if we are fair dinkum about people who have separated in a supposedly non-fault environment being able to rebuild their lives, then what we have to do is get this system right. that the statistics in my electorate office show that by far the largest number of inquiries, and the most emotional and most time consuming, relate to the Child Support Agency. Nobody in my office, including me, was in any way qualified to be able to deal with some of the problems and concerns that have come into the office. I must say that I have quickly learnt to be able to give some words of wisdom to some of the unfortunate victims of this particular government bureaucracy. Those words of wisdom are: no matter what you think of your partner, no matter how much you dislike your partner, go out and talk to your partner, find some sort of common ground and strike a deal, because the moment you walk away and look for a third party, that being the Child Support Agency, you are guaranteed to lose. Unfortunately, that is the reality of it; unfortunately also, with human nature, with the anger and bitterness associated with separation and a tug of war to try to inflict some sort of emotional gain through the children, it is not at all possible in most cases. Although, like any thinking Australian, I agree with the concept behind the child support scheme that parenthood has its price and responsibilities regardless of the state of a marriage and that taxpayers should not bear the burden of failed marriages, after the relatively short
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Entsch (Leichhardt) (9.33 P.m.)
theText: Like most members in this House, I have foundTuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4803 time that I have spent as a member, it seems obvious to me that the administration of the child support scheme has gone dramatically off the rails. Legislation before the House in this bill is aimed at correcting some minor flaws encountered in the scheme and I commend those changes to the House. But this legislation needs to go much further than these changes. It is my belief that the whole operation of the child support scheme needs to be revisited in the name of fairness to all. The question needs to be asked: what is the agenda driving this scheme and the agency that enforces it? Yet it has become readily apparent to me-and dare I say to the majority of members of this House-that the whole soul and structure of the child support scheme is in need of a dispassionate and all-encompassing review, with a new, fresh, fair and rational approach to be taken. Problems with the child support service were of such an intense and urgent nature that late last year I had to convene a child support forum in Cairns, the main population centre in my electorate, which attracted over 70 participants. One of the problems facing the victims of the current child support scheme that came out of this forum and from the electorate office inquiries is that it would appear that the whole core of the problem can probably be best addressed by the vision statement of the Lone Fathers Association of Australia. That is that all parties in the divorce situation, including the non-custodial parent, enjoy a fair and equitable distribution of financial resources emanating from a child support scheme and fair and equitable access to the children involved. Disregarding for the moment the attitudinal problems emanating from the CSA staff in their dealings with non-custodial parents, the two primary problems seem to be in the assessment levels of child-care contributions and the tax treatment of the CSS payments by contributing parents-the accountability of the money paid to the custodial parents through the scheme. Let me make one point very clear. In most of the dealings my office has had with noncustodial parents in the child support cases, there is absolutely no argument that a rational and reasonable level of contribution must be made towards the upkeep of children of failed marriages. Most non-custodial parents accept this fact and willingly accept the concept of maintenance. The problem is the methodology upon which the CSS is based and its enactment by the Child Support Agency. Firstly, on the assessment level, currently the formula used by the CSA is 18 per cent of gross wages for the first child, rising to 26 per cent of gross for five or more children. A major problem is in the use of the gross wage for the assessment purposes. The net effect of this payment to the average non-custodial parent can be as high as a third to half more in real dollar terms than those percentages reflect on paper. The government can take a major initiative in fairness by adjusting the formula to either a percentage of the net wage or by allowing the CSS payments to be tax deductible. The real effect of this arbitrary and unfair method of assessment is that many non-custodial parents are leaving the work force and going onto the dole, simply because they feel that they are better off on the dole than having to pay exorbitant levels of support demanded of them under the current system. If you have any doubts about this, you merely have to look at the number of non-custodial parents in receipt of unemployment benefits. Approximately 30 per cent currently have taken that option and that is more than three times the national unemployment average. So, by default, government action to recover child support payments and reduce the burden on the 4804 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 taxpayer have the opposite effect of encouraging people onto the dole, thereby costing the taxpayer seven or eight times more than it would cost just to pay child support in addition to the sole parent pension. Talk about a hollow victory. The problem with the assessment formula does not stop there. The anomaly between the level at which the Department of Social Security assesses the worth of the child and the level at which the CSA can assess the same child for higher income earners borders on the ridiculous. Standard DSS family payment for one child is $93.10 per fortnight. Yet a noncustodial parent on a basic wage is forced to pay $186.70 per fortnight, slightly more than double what the government considers to be the worth of a child. As the non-custodial parent's income gets higher, the contribution level per child becomes commensurately more out of step with reality. There is no differentiation as to the age of the child or children. For example, a three-year-old qualifies the custodial parent for the same rate of payment as does a 13-year-old, yet anyone would know that the cost of upkeep and education of a teenager is much higher than that of a toddler. There is no doubt that the real problem is the escalating divorce rate in Australia. As a government, we are committed to a return to family values and it devolves upon us to look at some of the major issues that are contributing to the current high level of family break-up in this nation. However, in the interim we have to look closely at how we can address the myriad of anomalies in the current child support scheme. Let us never lose sight of the real purpose of this scheme and our primary focus must always be on the innocent victims, the children. I must also acknowledge that in the majority of cases, both parents-and I repeat, both-have a deep love and intense interest in their children. Accountability of CSA payments in the hands of the custodial parents also seems to be one of the major problems associated with the scheme. This is a major source of conflict that I and my staff are hearing from non-custodial parents. The impression that they receive is that there is no accountability as to the direction of expenditure of CSA payments in the custodial parent's hands and that in many cases the money is used on expenditure totally unassociated with the care and upbringing of their child or children. Another concern is that when the custodial parent has taken up with another partner in a de facto relationship and both parties work, it is not uncommon to find a non-custodial parent reduced to poverty through a CSA ruling on maintenance while a custodial parent enjoys their own income, sometimes an income on a par with their ex-spouse, as well as the income of their de facto. I have heard of cases where a custodial parent in a new family situation and earning well in excess of $100,000 a year is receiving substantial CSA payments from an exspouse who is struggling to meet these payments, as well as having to cater for a new family on a single income. Possibly we, as a government, should look at setting up within the CSA a trust situation where the custodial parent is allowed to draw down regular maintenance payments from the moneys contributed by non-custodial parents for living costs and must account for all other major items of expenditure on the child or children for things such as education and other expenses. This would ensure that funds contributed by non-custodial parents are used exclusively for what they were intended, the maintenance and upbringing of the child. Another major area of concern that has been brought to my attention from dealing with people involved in the child support scheme is the problem of child access. There seems to be no relationship between demands to pay CSA payments and the paying parent's right to Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4805 access the child. The dogma of confidentiality is so entrenched in the bureaucrats at the Child Support Agency that non-custodial parents are often hounded for payments of child support, even when the custodial parent is ignoring decisions from the Family Court as regards access to children. It should be a two-way street. If the CSA is going to religiously enforce one law, the payment of child maintenance, then it should ensure that the other laws of a family nature are adhered to and that custodial parents abide by Family Court access decisions. I believe that this is only fair. Let us tum to the Child Support Agency itself. There are major attitudinal problems within the CSA that need addressing urgently. There would appear to be a regime of arrogance in place that in talks with my colleagues I have found to be almost universal across Australia. Non-custodial parents are treated in the main with contempt by the apparatchiks who staff this agency, which is totally contrary to the concept of a no fault divorce. If there is to be more than easy access to the tennination of marriage that seems to be the norm today, on the basis of no need to prove fault, then there should be no fault attributed to dealings with either the divorced or separated couple. This does not appear to be the case with the CSA. Almost every case that is brought to my office's attention includes an element of dissatisfaction with the attitudes of people in the CSA. Besides problems of arrogance and assumed guilt, there seems to be no continuity of dealing with staff. Non-custodial parents rarely speak to the same case officer twice and arbitrary decisions without any semblance of concern for the well-being of the non-custodial parent, or in many cases for their new family, bring about hardships beyond the nonnal human compassion. This goes both ways. It is not only the non-custodial parent that suffers from the shortcomings of the CSA. There seems to be a regime within the CSA of taking the easy way out. I have a particular case in my electorate where a non-custodial father, very well-known around the town as being, if not a millionaire, verging on that asset level, has structured his affairs in such a way that he has managed to bring his child support payments down to a mere $30 a week, some $17 a week less than his estranged wife could get in family benefits, forcing his estranged wife to try and raise their daughter on something like $100 a week after mortgage payments. Yet this gentleman has three booming businesses in Far North Queensland, a large and profitable painting business offshore, and a new one starting in Cairns. He lives in a $650,000 home in an exclusive beach suburb to which he recently added a $50,000 swimming pool and he recently bought his current girlfriend a $100,000 luxury motor car. You can see quite clearly that it goes both ways. I think this is another area that we have to look at very seriously, where people are able to conceal their income and, in doing so, are able to walk away from their commitment of contributing to payments for the upbringing of their children. It seems that, in that case, the CSA found it too hard to research this man's assets and income to realise that he has a very smart accountant and is conning the agency. This government is in a unique position to put a new broom through much of the anti-family legislation that we have inherited. I believe the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) when he says that he wants to run a government that returns this nation to traditional family values that once made it a much more stable society than it is today after 13 years of social engineering. This bill is a small start to cleaning up some of the surface anomalies in the child support legi4806 MAIN COMMITIEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 slation, but we certainly need to go much, much deeper. We need to go right to the heart of this act and bring to it fairness, accountability and justice for all concerned. I am an active member of the recently established government backbench committee dealing with child support legislation, and I am certainly looking forward to changes that we hope will be introduced later this year. There are literally hundreds and thousands of Australians out there, both custodial and non-custodial parents, who are haemorrhaging under the socially libertine attacks on the institution of marriage this act encourages. They say that from acorns great oaks grow. I commend this bill to the House, primarily in the hope that it is a first small step in returning justice and fair treatment to what is one of the major social engineering failures of this and the previous decade. Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996. Since being elected to represent the people of Makin in this place, I have received many requests for assistance in matters relating to child support and the Child Support Agency. It was a matter I raised in my first speech in the House. As a result of many constituent inquiries I have received on this issue, I have made numerous representations to the then Assistant Treasurer, Senator Jim Short and the current Assistant Treasurer, Senator Rod Kemp. They have, on each and every occasion, been willing to listen to my requests and have been extremely helpful in seeking a resolution to the particular problem I have been seeking to resolve on behalf of my constituents and, most importantly, their children. As a result of representations from government members, me included, the Assistant Treasurer and the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, have established a committee to investigate suggested changes to the child support system. As a member of this committee, I appreciate the opportunity to bring the concerns of my constituents directly to the ministers responsible for the operation of the agency and related services. I place on record my appreciation of the fine work being done by the staff of the Child Support Agency in Adelaide, South Australia. Their work can sometimes be very difficult and distressing, but I have always found them ready and willing to help to the best of their ability, even though the outcomes are not always what both parents would wish. The establishment of the Child Support Agency has had a significant effect on the number of non-custodial parents who now pay child support. Prior to its introduction, it is estimated that only one in three non-custodial parents was paying child support. This compares with the current situation where 56 per cent of all collect cases pay child support each and every month. Furthermore, surveys that have been taken suggest that about 85 per cent of registered private collection cases pay regularly. This means that around 65 per cent of registered payers now make regular payments to support their children. These figures illustrate the general success of the agency in ensuring that both parents contribute towards the upbringing of their child or children. Despite this, however, we recognise that there are problems and inequities within the current system. Over the last three years, the number of cases being dealt with by the Child Support Agency has increased by around 50,000 per year, and this is expected to continue. At the end of last year, there were 247,000 collect cases in the system and a further 164,000 registered private collection cases.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mrs Draper (Makin) (9.49 P.m.)
theText: It gives me much pleasure to speak in support of theTuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4807 The Howard government's 1996-97 budget recognised the necessity of reforming aspects of the system and provided additional resources to the Child Support Agency. As a result of the reforms already made by the government, child support collections increased by $36 million in the 12 months between December 1995 and December 1996, and the amount of child support debt was reduced. Some 80 per cent of total child support liability was collected and distributed to custodial parents, and the number of payers having their arrears directly deducted from their wages increased by more than 4,000. There is still a need for further improvement, as my constituents will testify, but I am sure that all Australians would be pleased with the progress so far. The issue of the repayment of overpayments by custodial parents has been raised with me on several occasions. On one occasion, a distressed constituent contacted me after receiving a letter from the Child Support Agency requesting her to repay a sum of money. The constituent had already used the money to provide her two children with the opportunity to visit their grandparents in Victoria. She could not afford to travel with them and had had to scrimp and save to provide them with enough money for the trip. The letter from the agency was a very unpleasant shock to her and she did not know what to do. Thankfully, assistance was provided and her two children got to see their grandparents, but this highlights one of the problems which currently exists and, I am pleased to say, it is being addressed in this bill. As members would be aware, child support assessments are calculated using the income tax returns of the payer for the previous two years. If the payer feels that his or her income for the current year will be more than 15 per cent less than previously estimated, he or she can have their child support payments reassessed. This estimate affects the child support payments from the beginning of the financial year, meaning that the custodial parent may have to refund money which has already been paid. To illustrate this point, I wish to mention another case which was brought to my attention by one of my constituents. On this occasion, the custodial parent had been overpaid and was required to repay the money. However, the estimate given by the payer had been incorrect and he had, in fact, earned more than his estimate. The result was that my constituent had to pay back all of the amount she was overpaid and then would receive back part of this after the adjustment was made for the payer's incorrect estimate. She could not see the logic in this and, frankly, nor could I. This bill changes the way in which overpayments are recovered. A parent will no longer be required to refund money already paid. Overpayments will be recovered by reducing the non-custodial parent's payments for the year. Underpayments will also be made up over the period of the year, rather than all at once. It will still be a requirement for the correct and total amount of money for the year to be paid, but these changes will mean that far fewer custodial parents will be required to repay overpaid amounts of child support. This measure will also lead to a more accurate assessment of the non-custodial parent's future capacity to pay, because the amount payable will only be changed for the months remaining after the estimate has been lodged. The level of child support arrears should also be reduced as a result of these changes. Another improvement that will be implemented on the passage of this bill relates to the preferred method of payment by payers of their child support obligations. Currently, many payments are deducted directly from the non-custodial parent's wages by his or her employer and sent to the Child Support Agency. I know of a number of my constituents who are 4808 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 distressed by this lack of control over their own finances and who resent the fact that their employers are forced to become involved in a private matter. The changes in this bill will allow non-custodial parents to make payments directly to the Child Support Agency without the involvement of his or her employer. This is in line with the recommendations of the 1994 Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues-as is much of this bill. We must give credit to the work done by that committee. Naturally, this change to allow non-custodial parents to directly pay the agency is subject to the approval of the registrar. The registrar must be satisfied that the parent will pay on time. Custodial parents can be reassured by the fact that the registrar will be able to reverse the decision to allow direct payment if payments are not made on time. A payer parent who has had his or her application for direct payment rejected must wait two months before applying again for this method of payment. Similarly, a payer parent who has failed to make regular payments on time, using the direct payment method, may have the employer deductions reintroduced and must wait six months before applying again for the direct payment method. These provisions safeguard the custodial parent, whilst giving the opportunity to noncustodial parents to make regular direct payments to the Child Support Agency. Furthermore, this measure is in line with the government's stated aim of supporting small business. By providing the option of direct payments by the payer parents, the responsibility and associated compliance costs to employers will be reduced. A further aspect of this bill that will please non-custodial parents, in particular, is the provision to amend the Family Law Act 1975 to enable the court to consider future child support liabilities in property and spousal maintenance proceedings. This will apply even without an administrative assessment under the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989. I have received many representations from non-custodial parents who feel that their child support arrangements are unfair and do not take into full account their financial position. The anger and emotion of some of these parents illustrates the need to ensure fairness and equity in dealing with issues relating to child support and family law. There have been cases where there has been no child support assessment applied for when the custodial parent has applied for child support arrears after the property settlement has been determined. In such cases, the child support liability has not been taken into consideration, to the detriment of the payer parent. Amendments in this bill will allow payer parents to have these future child support obligations recognised and taken into account by the Family Court before the settlement of property and spousal maintenance. This is both fair and equitable, and in line with the Howard government's commitment to the implementation of positive reforms to child support arrangements. I must comment on the breathtaking audacity of the member for Werriwa( Mr Latham) during his contribution to this debate. The member for Werriwa has suddenly become a latter day champion of reform in the area of child support arrangements. Never mind that, in 13 years of Labor, nothing was done to make the system fairer; never mind that the thousands of Australians who held genuine grievances concerning this matter were ignored by Labor ministers and by an unsympathetic Labor government. I know the stories, and I have seen the heartbreak caused by the callous attitude that Labor has towards people. But we now have the member for Werriwa whingeing and complaining Tuesday, 3 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 4809 that the Howard coalition government is not doing enough. The honourable member moves amendments designed to play politics with people's sensitivities, yet he does not recognise the absolute failure of his own previous Labor government to do anything to improve the system when they had the chance. We now have substantial reforms before us which will help to make child support arrangements fairer and more equitable. The member for Werriwa ought to reflect on that. He ought to remember that the improvements are taking place under the Howard coalition government. This government has proven willing to listen and act on matters relating to child support. I am very pleased to be able to bring the concerns of my constituents directly to the minister responsible. The establishment of a government committee on the Child Support Agency has enabled government members to voice the concerns of their constituents and work on finding practical solutions. There were over 6,000 public submissions to the 1994 Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. This reflects the very real need for the reforms contained within this bill, and for an ongoing process of reform to further improve the system of child support. I believe in the need for further considered reform to ensure even greater fairness and equity. As I said in my first speech in the House, many constituents feel that the child support formula is unfair because it is calculated on taxable income minus exempt income, rather than on net income, which is the amount of money that the non-custodial parent has to live on in real terms. I said at that time, and I say it again today, that I will continue to work towards a fairer system for both custodial and non-custodial parents in my electorate of Makin and Australia wide, for the benefit of all children. to commence by thanking many members for their contributions to the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996. In effect, all members from both sides of the parliament have supported the contents of this bill. The number of speakers to this bill indicates the amount of interest in parliament with the operation of the child support scheme. Firstly, I would like to respond to the amendment moved by the member for Werriwa( Mr Latham) on behalf of the opposition. For obvious reasons, the government will not be supporting this amendment. As the member for Makin( Mrs Draper) has very adequately and eloquently said, the opposition-the member for Werriwa in this case-are moving amendments when they had 13 years to do something about this issue. It is gross hypocrisy to come here and criticise us when we have been in government for only 15 months. We are responding, and we are responding in a very significant way. For the record, the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues reported in November 1994. That committee made 163 recommendations for change to the Child Support Agency and to the scheme in general. At the time that the coalition government took office, more than 100 of the recommendations from this committee had not been responded to. Those that were addressed by the previous government were largely administrative. The recommendations left to this government, not surprisingly, are more substantive and more complex. For the most part, the remaining recommendations from the report of the joint select committee involve complex issues of equity between separated parents, their children and the Commonwealth.

speaker: Mr Bruce Scott (Maranoa
theText: Minister for Veterans' Affairs) (10.03 p.m.)-I would like4810 MAIN COMMITTEE Tuesday, 3 June 1997 As many members have indicated, the government is giving careful consideration to the operation of the scheme and, in particular, to the remaining recommendations from the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. This is in stark contrast to the previous government. I note with interest the remarks made earlier this week by the honourable member for Chifley( Mr Price), chair of the joint select committee, when speaking on his private member's bill in relation to this matter. He said: ... it never occurred to me that nearly three years would have elapsed and that only the easiest of the recommendations-53 in all-would have been tackled by my governmentthe Labor government when they were in powerand the present government and that the remaining more difficult policy issues would be and continue to be unresponded to ... In fact, if I reflect on the three years, I am a little surprised that the caucus has never really had an opportunity to vote on these measures or any of the other recommendations. That is from Hansard, 2 June, 1997. This is the government's first legislative response to recommendations made by the joint select committee. The government recognises that this bill does not address the key issues of the joint select committee. However, the government does not believe that these common sense reforms should await consideration of the somewhat more substantial issues raised by the joint select committee and many others in the community. Nothing says more about the priority given to child support by the previous government than the fact that the first legislative response to the committee had to await the advent of a coalition government to be introduced. The bill amends the child support legislation to bring it into line with the provisions and concepts of the Social Security Act 1991, the Family Law Act 1975 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. Each of these acts has undergone change over the last few years without at the time making the necessary consequential changes to child support legislation. The bill amends the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 to adopt the thrust of recommendation 124 of the joint select committee on the use of income estimates. This amendment will allow estimates for the most part to have a prospective effect only. This will reduce the incidence of overpayments to persons receiving child support by removing the retrospective effect of the current income estimate provisions. The bill amends the Child Support (Registration Collection) Act 1988 to enable parents who pay child support to elect to pay directly to the register. This amendment adopts recommendations 55 through to 57 of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. It reduces the level of intrusiveness of the child support scheme where payers voluntarily comply with their child support obligations and over time may reduce the administrative and compliance costs of the scheme. The amendment provides a better balance between the need for regular financial support for children of separated parents and the rights of parents to privacy. The bill also amends the Family Law Act 1975 to allow the courts to take into account the child support liability of a person in property and spousal maintenance proceedings, even where a child support assessment has not been issued. The amendment responds to recommendations 156 of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. The reforms proposed in the bill are responsible. They remove some significant and frequent causes for complaint from payers and recipients of child support. They are, to use the words of the member for Dunkley( Mr Billson) 'human and responsive reforms'. They represent a small step in responding to the outstanding recommendations from the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues and I commend the bill to the Main Committee.
